The third tier of the library was added in the 1800s, and the tables and bookshelves were fenced off in the 1980s when people started defacing them.

436695750.name: Impressive library
436695750.author: a TripAdvisor user
436695750.reviewBody: It is the oldest library in Latin America with a huge collection of books. The interior is very impressive and some of the ancient books with maps are on display. As it is close to the cathedral, certainly worthwhile to stop by. It is on the first floor and one big hall.

435906905.name: Great historical and literary place
435906905.author: a TripAdvisor user
435906905.reviewBody:
I was in the city of Puebla from 6th to 14th October 2016. I visited Biblioteca Palafoxiana.
First of all I am grateful to the bishop pf PieblaJuan who has given the people of Puebla this great literary place.
The bookshelves are marvellous. The old manuscripts are marvellous. The Ipads placed with all information are great contribution. With a touch of finger you have all information at your finger tips and you have to turn your head to see them.
The place is excellent historical and educational place. it is great place for children.

432244370.name: Oldest in library in Mexico.
432244370.author: a TripAdvisor user
432244370.reviewBody: This was so exciting to visit! It was small, but you could feel the history just oozing out of the books. It cost to get in, but was only about $1.50 US. Worth it! You can\'t touch or open any of the books, but they do have a few open under glass cases to view.

431436432.name: Nice place to see
431436432.author: a TripAdvisor user
431436432.reviewBody: The Biblioteca is very central and is a nice place to visit. There is an antique feeling to it, with decent amount of books. Be sure to wonder through the building itself. I ended up like that in an interesting courtyard :)

430380795.name: If you LOVE books ....
430380795.author: a TripAdvisor user
430380795.reviewBody: The Biblioteca is located close to the Zocalo.  It is definitely worth a visit to see the beautiful library and books ... some of which date back 100s of years.  It will only take about 10 - 15 minutes to walk around the room.  There is an entrance charge.

428886041.name: Must Be Seen to be Appreciated
428886041.author: a TripAdvisor user
428886041.reviewBody: This library, one of the oldest in the America\'s,  if not THE oldest, is worth the small price of admission (25 pesos / person). While you cannot took virtually anything in the room, simply being in it give you a sense of history and the importance of books, reading, and education have played within Mexican society. Many libraries have stood the test of time and this one is no exception. Spend the few pesos to experience a part of history.

427968332.name: Stunning
427968332.author: a TripAdvisor user
427968332.reviewBody: One of the most beautiful libraries I have ever visited. $25 entry but worth every peso. The decor is divine

427736017.name: An old library room
427736017.author: a TripAdvisor user
427736017.reviewBody: OK, it was the end of the day and my feet hurt and I was expecting more than the photo in the brochure.  I get it, it is an old library.  I love books, I respect that and enjoyed the few volumes, 600 years old, that were open.  So that will cost you 25 pesos and about ten minutes of your time.  Totally disinterested in the four gallery rooms.  Sorry to not be able to be more enthused.  You might want to grab on to the English tour guide and escort you.

427648935.name: Unbelievable!
427648935.author: a TripAdvisor user
427648935.reviewBody: Fantastic thing to see! It is the oldest library in the Americas. This used to be a church, so the architecture is incredible. The books date back hundreds of years. Our guide was fabulous, and spoke several languages so no problem for anyone hear the valuable information. The energy of the place was amazing.

424808956.name: One of a Kind in the Americas
424808956.author: a TripAdvisor user
424808956.reviewBody: Don\'t miss a walk through this place to see what a library looked like 500 years ago. You can have a guide if you choose too. Especially look at the classifications of subjects, the drawing by Kepler the astronomer and at the far corner on the right up above that says "historia profana" or profane history. Although I couldn\'t get up there to see what kind of books they had, I was awfully curious! Beautiful Place.

424414623.name: A Visit is Mandatory
424414623.author: a TripAdvisor user
424414623.reviewBody: This amazing, historically significant place, the oldest library in the Nuevo Mundo, must be one of the places you visit in Puebla. It is beautifully preserved.

423840422.name: A magnificent piece of history!
423840422.author: a TripAdvisor user
423840422.reviewBody: We visit on a Sunday morning, there was a \u00b4show\u00b4downstairs in the entrance to the library. It was free and the dancing and music was fantastic, I do not know if this happens every Sunday morning, it added to the enjoyment! The library is fantastic, very historic, the guide spoke English which was great. The smell of the old wood was very nice. Well worth a look.

420520058.name: Awesome
420520058.author: a TripAdvisor user
420520058.reviewBody: Not very big but beautiful. I think it is the oldest library in the Americas. If not....close. A beautiful retablo also.

419996080.name: A must to visit in Puebla
419996080.author: a TripAdvisor user
419996080.reviewBody: This is a must in Puebla. We all learned so many interesting facts!\nWe were a large group of family and kids, everyone enjoyed!\nWe just loved it!

417741849.name: Amazing
417741849.author: a TripAdvisor user
417741849.reviewBody: Located in the same street as the Cathedral, the Biblioteca Palafoxiana is definitely a must see. With over 41,000 books dating from the 15th century, this library is the said to be the first pubic library in the Americas. It is impressive to see the books perfectly ordered, however, it is always enriching to hear the explanation of them from a certified guide. I repeat, definitely a must see!

415834593.name: A hidden jewel in downtown Puebla
415834593.author: a TripAdvisor user
415834593.reviewBody: One of the most beautiful Libraries in the world. Its not very well promoted among the touristic things to see in Puebla, but definetly a must see!!

415128395.name: A must do when in Puebla
415128395.author: a TripAdvisor user
415128395.reviewBody: The oldest library in the new world, I\'m amazaed at the condition of the books and artifacts. I can olny imagine what it may have been like to come and have studied here 200+ years ago, whata privilage that must have been.

414750934.name: Fascinating
414750934.author: a TripAdvisor user
414750934.reviewBody: Beautiful and fascinating place. You cannot walk in as the library accessible for accredited professionals only Even though you cannot check out books, you certainly can see the place. Worth checking it out!

414316868.name: Wonderful old library
414316868.author: a TripAdvisor user
414316868.reviewBody: One of the must see sites in Pueble. It is apparently the oldest library in the Americas, all wood panelled. There is a guide by the door who you can hire to take you round and is very knowledgable.

412707218.name: Books of Old
412707218.author: a TripAdvisor user
412707218.reviewBody: Incredibly beautiful library with 41,000 books. They were contributed from various people from the 15th to 20th century. It is no longer a public library but if one is doing research they are allowed to use the books. The shelves are beautifully crafted and the furniture on display is as old and charming as the library itself.

410308288.name: Overwhelming
410308288.author: a TripAdvisor user
410308288.reviewBody: One feels little and so unimportant facing such treasures who have travelled through time. Short visit but a MUST!

408078797.name: This was so cool!
408078797.author: a TripAdvisor user
408078797.reviewBody: An absolutely gorgeous library with old books. Not much you can do other than look but still well worth the few minutes and pesos.

406728953.name: Beautiful Library
406728953.author: a TripAdvisor user
406728953.reviewBody: Extraordinary collection of books encased in beautifully wood decorated cases. Similar to the Library at the Strahov Monastery in Prague.

402252373.name: Interesting, historic and beautiful
402252373.author: a TripAdvisor user
402252373.reviewBody: This was the first public library of America! It has amazing architecture and design and books from the xv century and more.It is only 25 pesos (less than 2 usd). It is worth to ask the guide for a brief tour.\n\nYou can actually look through any of the books in there by requesting permission in advance.

392897532.name: Beautiful library
392897532.author: a TripAdvisor user
392897532.reviewBody: This is a beautiful library like 10 meters tall made in wood with two levels. \n\nIt doesn\'t take more than 20 minutes to visit it. It shows around 10 selected books. It says it is the oldest library in Mexico. Very nicely handcrafted and in perfect conditions.

388861873.name: A Mexican Colonial Barroque Jewel
388861873.author: a TripAdvisor user
388861873.reviewBody: Located in a spectacular building by the Puebla Cathedral, Biblioteca Palafoxiana is a world class cultural site to visit.  Amazing how all the treasures were preserved and kept in the present pristine condition.

384726267.name: Nice place to visit if you love books!
384726267.author: a TripAdvisor user
384726267.reviewBody: I loved visiting the Biblioteca Palafoxiana. It is a beautiful library, with three floors of old books! Scholars can still study the books in the library, but only the first floor is open for viewing for the public. They offered a free tour of the library (in Spanish), which was worth doing to learn more about the library. Definitely worth a visit while you are in Puebla!

382482145.name: Awe-inspiring
382482145.author: a TripAdvisor user
382482145.reviewBody: This library was a very humbling experience for us. You don\'t expect the walls of books to surround and envelop you like they do. You have to visit it.

378778495.name: More than a library space
378778495.author: a TripAdvisor user
378778495.reviewBody: While the upstairs historic library is wonderful, keep an eye out also for traveling exhibits. While we were in Puebla, a beautiful exhibit of photos and handcrafts was in the downstairs courtyard from Oaxaca - stunning collection! A real treat.

378687613.name: Unforgettable
378687613.author: a TripAdvisor user
378687613.reviewBody: Before you visit read Wikipedia on Bishop Palafox to get a better understanding of the magnitude of his endeavor. This library could be in Chatsworth or Sandringham House. It is quite the labor of love of a decidedly Renaissance man who was an unapologetic liberal with a sense of real justice for all. The wooden balustrades, the wooden globes, and everything else about the collection is awe inspiring.

376463868.name: Worth a walk by
376463868.author: a TripAdvisor user
376463868.reviewBody: Library has historic feel. The signs aren\'t too clear how to get in so it is easy to get mixed up and go into the museum next door. Once you find the place the courtyard is nice. I thought it was worth taking 5 minutes to walk by.

375550705.name: beautiful upon entering
375550705.author: a TripAdvisor user
375550705.reviewBody: gorgeous presentation.  impressive collection, easy to tours.  good explanations.  must see.  it does look like the photos

370527981.name: Old and proud
370527981.author: a TripAdvisor user
370527981.reviewBody: This room on the second floor of the arts museum behind the Cathedral in the Centro, houses books dating back 500 years.  It is one of the most important in Spanish America.  The housing for the books is old, old timber made to a high standard.  M$25 entrance fee.

368425449.name: Take a guide please and you will love it even more
368425449.author: a TripAdvisor user
368425449.reviewBody: Located in the casa de la cultura it is not an easy find; however, when you get inside, just go upstairs, pay the entrance fee (about 3 or 4 bucks) and ask for a guide. The people who work here are very passionate about telling the library\'s history. It is a quick stop that will take you between 30 and 45 minutes, absolutely worth it.

367338028.name: Wonderful
367338028.author: a TripAdvisor user
367338028.reviewBody: This is the oldest public library in the new world, which alone makes it worth a visit. The labrary is located on the upper floor of the casa de cultura, across the street from the south side of the Cathedral.  There is a small admission charge. The woodwork is baroque and lovely. There are revolving exhibits of library related stuff. The Casa itself also has revolving exhibits of contemporary local artists.

364675968.name: Quick and easy and well worth a visit
364675968.author: a TripAdvisor user
364675968.reviewBody: This is an interesting place to visit on your tour of the city. It doesn\'t take long and is not expensive but it a lovely tranquil place.

363496015.name: Excellent but very hard to find
363496015.author: a TripAdvisor user
363496015.reviewBody: I looked and looked for this because it was something I really wanted to see.  I would have missed it again if a man hadn\'t asked me from the doorway "Do you want to see the library?"  Even after entering the complex I had a hard time finding the library, and the ticket purchase location was not marked.  If you are interested in old books, though, it is worth the frustration of finding it.  Supremely preserved!

360702841.name: Visiting The First Library of the Americas
360702841.author: a TripAdvisor user
360702841.reviewBody: One of the highlights of our recent trip to Puebla was visiting the Palafoxiana Library behind the Cathedral and next to the Tourist Center.  This incredibly beautiful library dates from the 1600\'s.  In fact, it is the first library of the Americas.  The bishop of Oaxaca, Juan Palafox y Mendoza donated 5000 volumes in 1646 and offered any literate person of the region access to them.  They are housed in a former convent on the second floor in a marvelous setting of polished old wooden shelves reaching from floor to ceiling with a religious shrine at the far end.  Most of the ancient texts cover Moral Theology, Dogma, Church History, Ecclesiastical matters, etc.  Photography (no flash) is allowed.  Admission to the library/museum is about $1.20.  Highly recommended.

359583202.name: ATreasure displayed!
359583202.author: a TripAdvisor user
359583202.reviewBody: The collection of over 45,000 old books is not only appealing, it is impresive.The building is also very nice. I you can have a guide a bit of history enhances the visit enormously.

359417256.name: Hard to find but worth it!
359417256.author: a TripAdvisor user
359417256.reviewBody: If you go walking by the street and look for this great library you won\'t find it so easily. It\'s located in a building aside Cathedral, you need to go inside (no signals available) and when you go upstairs you will find it.\n\nA great place with a great history.

357435759.name: Use a guide
357435759.author: a TripAdvisor user
357435759.reviewBody: Our visit to the biblioteca was so enriched by asking the guide to provide us with a tour in English.  He spoke a number of other languages as well.  The room is beautiful and if you love libraries just being in the place is worth the visit.  The tour helped us learn some of the nuances of the library not mentioned in the guide books, provided some additional info about talavara pottery ( there are tiles embedded in the floor) and gain an additional appreciation for the founder Palafoxiana.

356657880.name: A must see while in Puebla. Real unique.
356657880.author: a TripAdvisor user
356657880.reviewBody: There aren\'t many places like this in the whole Mexico. The level of conservancy and the collection preserved there are extremely rare in the whole American continent. So it is very well worth the visit!

355875786.name: Has to be one of the world\u00b4s best libraries!
355875786.author: a TripAdvisor user
355875786.reviewBody: The collection of historical books is overwhelming!  The stunning beauty of the woodwork throughout and the silence of the library are all just marvelous!  A must see in Puebla!\nThere is a very small admission price, and a local guide is available for hire, at a modest tip.

355465735.name: Gorgeous books and architecture
355465735.author: a TripAdvisor user
355465735.reviewBody: I loved this library. The carved wood shelves, balustrades and furniture create a somber and beautiful atmosphere for the large collection of , mostly religious, book. At the far end of the room is a large conference table with carved chairs, and an altar. The altar brings  a particular  reverence to the library. There is also an excellent display of St. Teresa of Avilla and also a wonderful interactive model of the basilica included in the entry fee for the library. An inexpensive and  fascinating way to spend an hour or so.

353180606.name: Take a look!
353180606.author: a TripAdvisor user
353180606.reviewBody: The history of this library is amazing! We did not know about it. If you want to enter, there is a small admission fee, but otherwise you are able to view from the door way (but no pictures).

351215474.name: Intriguing
351215474.author: a TripAdvisor user
351215474.reviewBody: Beautiful library with books dating back to mid 1400\'s. Definitely worth at least a quick visit. If you understand Spanish, ask for a tour...

350627595.name: Go for the Architecture & History
350627595.author: a TripAdvisor user
350627595.reviewBody:
A library guard saw us on the street (Ave 5 Ore #5 next to the tourist office) trying to find the place (its on the second floor interior).  He offered a free tour in English with a tip after if we were satisfied.  First you have buy tickets ($25 Pesos each).  It is worth checking it out for its history and architecture.

The Biblioteca Palafoxiana's namesake, Juan Palafox y Mendoza, was bishop of Puebla from 1640 to 1655, and served as viceroy of New Spain. In 1646 he donated 5000 books from his private collection to the seminary of the Colegio de San Juan. He made the donation with the stipulation that the books be available to any literate person, and not just academics, thus establishing the first public library of the Americas. 

In 1773, Bishop Francisco Fabian y Fuero commissioned bookshelves made of finely carved cedar, ayacahuite pine, and coloyote wood to house the library's growing collection. An additional tier of shelving was added in the 1800s.

The former Colegio de San Juan is now home to Puebla's Casa de la Cultura cultural center, but the Biblioteca Palafoxiana remains in its original location on the second floor. It occupies a long vaulted hall with a splendid altarpiece from the mid 14th century gracing the far end. The altarpiece is covered with gold leaf, and the center is dominated by a painting of the Madonna of Trapani by Sicilian master Nino Pisano. 

The library has been recognized for its antiquity, originality and artistic value: in 1981, the Mexican government declared it a historic monument and in 2005, UNESCO added it to the Memory of the World list. A digital catalog of the library's collection was released in 2010.

348945794.name: Fascinating!
348945794.author: a TripAdvisor user
348945794.reviewBody: One of the oldest surviving libraries in the western hemisphere.  A don\'t miss when visiting Puebla. Volumes dating back to the 1500\'s, some of them unique.

347205740.name: History of the continent on display
347205740.author: a TripAdvisor user
347205740.reviewBody: The library is only one room, albeit one of great historical significance.  The globes and large painting of the Madonna encapsulate the motivation behind the Spanish conquest.  Browse the glass displays for insight into perceptions of native people in the 17th century.  The local Catholic church maintains additional exhibition space on the same floor; when I visited, there was a fascinating display on the life of Saint Teresa of Avila.

343409296.name: A truly beatiful and inspiring place
343409296.author: a TripAdvisor user
343409296.reviewBody: The Biblioteca Palafoxiana is located near the Zocalo of Puebla, and it is a mandatory visit for those who loves libraries, specially the ones with history. It is a historic landmark of Puebla and the architecture of the place is awsome.

342823408.name: Very old books \ud83d\ude00
342823408.author: a TripAdvisor user
342823408.reviewBody: This place was really nice. I really wish I\'d have such a beautiful libary by my own. The price is with 25 Mex$ very reasonable.\nIf you love book, you have to go there.

339519900.name: Well hidden
339519900.author: a TripAdvisor user
339519900.reviewBody: Not so easy to find in the Casa de la Cultura, one of 2 or more museums sharing this enormous building. It merits a detour and a lot of time to peruse all the vthe volumes.

338571780.name: an historical library
338571780.author: a TripAdvisor user
338571780.reviewBody: one of the most beautiful libraries of the whole world. Nice paintings on the ceiling and an very great collection of old books.

338184109.name: Nice collection
338184109.author: a TripAdvisor user
338184109.reviewBody: This Library is very nice, you get to see books that are 200 or more years old. What I did not like is that the sun shines on them and that is not very good for old books. They do not let you use flash on your camera but the sun rays are ok. I think Puebla has a problem with taking care of monuments.

337548565.name: What a great place to visit
337548565.author: a TripAdvisor user
337548565.reviewBody: A great place to see, feel and smell Mexican history. It\'s amazing how all those books have been conserved through the years. Personnel on site provide excellent explanations and are always willing to answer your questions.

337388830.name: Quite lovely architecture
337388830.author: a TripAdvisor user
337388830.reviewBody: Check out the interesting architectural elements of this building. Lots of attractive features that were unexpected.

327891008.name: Worth a look
327891008.author: a TripAdvisor user
327891008.reviewBody: Right in the centre of town so worth a visit. I\'m not really in to libraries myself but it was interesting to see a library that has been around since 1646!! And is widely considered to be the first library In the Americas. Kind of crazy when you think about it. Entry fee is 25 pesos per person. The style and architecture is impressive and looking at books that are around 500 years old is pretty neat.

327156981.name: Great Place, Lazy Staff
327156981.author: a TripAdvisor user
327156981.reviewBody: Beautiful architectural detail, although all of the old books are out in the open and without climate control. We wondered about the longterm preservation of this historic collection. Unfortunately, the indifferent staff working that day could not have cared less about their work. Also the security guard lied to us about the availability of the bathroom. I wish this behavior was an aberration, but sadly this was a common occurrence on our trip.

326043879.name: breathtaking architectural detail
326043879.author: a TripAdvisor user
326043879.reviewBody: Well worth a stop if you\'re in Puebla. Part of the Carolino administrative building of the University of Puebla (officially known as "Benemerita Autonoma Universidad de Puebla [BUAP]"), you will likely need someone with a key to get you in.  Ask at the entrance.  You can feel the centuries of history here.

323392716.name: Very immpressive
323392716.author: a TripAdvisor user
323392716.reviewBody: The stacks and woodwork were beautiful and worth the walk to find the place.  The student who was working informative and with the sun shining in the windows it was a place of beauty and solitude filled with books...what could be better?

321928759.name: Impressive!
321928759.author: a TripAdvisor user
321928759.reviewBody: Very nice library. It is free to to walk through the library. Althought there are people outside trying to make a buck will try to assist you. it\'s a beautiful library.

316597154.name: Historical wonder in the center of Puebla
316597154.author: a TripAdvisor user
316597154.reviewBody: A beautifully preserved library filled with ancient books and manuscripts.  One side of the library has windows and the shafts of light cast an intriguing glow over the space. The intricate staircases, bookshelves and furniture surround you and the book themselves are fascinating.  It\'s just a single room, but for the small entrance fee, there is a lot to see and it is unlikely you will see anything like this again.

312953764.name: Beautiful!!
312953764.author: a TripAdvisor user
312953764.reviewBody: It only takes a glimpse to realize you have just stepped in one of the most beautiful libraries in the world. So, even if you don\'t like books, even if you don\'t like arts and museums, and even if you have never read a book... please step inside for at least a second and you WILL be surprised. The only other place where I have seen such a beautiful library is Morelia (a sort of twin city of Puebla in terms of looks - especially of its zocalo and city centre). A few inches from your eyes you\'ll see books written 5 centuries ago... but don\'t touch!

311408674.name: very impressive Door
311408674.author: a TripAdvisor user
311408674.reviewBody: With a beautiful impressive door, this building is worth the time to go and see. Counting with very old volumes.

302877643.name: A must see
302877643.author: a TripAdvisor user
302877643.reviewBody: This library has been in existence since the 17th century. It is claimed by some to be the oldest in the Americas. The room is brilliant and some of the contents date back to the late 15th century. Try and guess what the wheel shaped stand near the front door is used for.\nTo gain access, walk into the Centro Cultural past the guard (he offers a tour at a fee but all it is is a 15 minute speech) and go up the stairs. Once you pay your fee you gain entry.

301248364.name: Beautiful library
301248364.author: a TripAdvisor user
301248364.reviewBody: Most of the sights in Puebla are churches, so this spectacular library very much worth visiting, you wont see another one like it!

300637149.name: Great! Go on Sunday
300637149.author: a TripAdvisor user
300637149.reviewBody: This is a great place to visit. Go on Sunday as its free. We paid a guide a small fee to spend 15 minutes explaining the history of the library, it was well worth it.

298505747.name: Great library.
298505747.author: a TripAdvisor user
298505747.reviewBody: One of the oldest private libraries in the "new world". It contains many old books and several languages.

297906488.name: Wonderful Collection
297906488.author: a TripAdvisor user
297906488.reviewBody: What a wonderful collection of ancient manuscripts kept in this ancient library. Takes very little time to tour this library but worth it if you appreciate the value of literature and cultures. Contains books several hundred years old on display.

295921699.name: First Library in the Americas
295921699.author: a TripAdvisor user
295921699.reviewBody: This library is located in a cultural building and is a bit tricky to find. When you walk up the stairs you can purchase tickets on the left and then head into the library. It is small but fascinating and beautifully preserved.

291535028.name: Interesting
291535028.author: a TripAdvisor user
291535028.reviewBody: Interesting visit, it is the biggest religious library in LatinAmerica, it is really well mantained and very interesting to see, they charge $40.00 if i recall correctly, it is small in size but i guess that the price is worth it for them to keep it as it is

290739084.name: The First Library in America!
290739084.author: a TripAdvisor user
290739084.reviewBody: This is a very small library, but the first in North America!! I love history, I love books - this is well worth the visit. The ticket office isn\'t well marked, but the  friendly person sitting at the entrace will direct you there (they have to tell basically every single person that they have to buy a ticket and direct them, you\'d think directional signage to that end would have come up at a staff meeting, or something). You can\'t go up to the upper levels, and the books on the main level are behind a screen, but it\'s fantastic.

286943884.name: a very nice and beautifull library
286943884.author: a TripAdvisor user
286943884.reviewBody: this library is from the 17 th century and its a beautifull place to visit and very relaxing and its a vvery old and special histic place to see

286216946.name: Beautiful
286216946.author: a TripAdvisor user
286216946.reviewBody: Always pick up the guides inside the library never the ones from outside because they don\'t know very well the story and sometimes tell you lies.  Nevertheless,  an excellent place to visit small but worth the price,  "the first library in all America".

284378203.name: Historic Landmark
284378203.author: a TripAdvisor user
284378203.reviewBody: A great piece of Mexican history.   For those who love libraries, this is a must see.   Beautiful architecture and wonderful sources of Mexican history

280523024.name: Indiana Jones Style
280523024.author: a TripAdvisor user
280523024.reviewBody: This small but beautiful library seems like something out of an Indiana jones movie.  I feel like you could break through the floor and find a secret tunnel.  The only major issue was that the people working there were not hugely knowledgeable about the library.

279603218.name: A must see: oldest library in Latin America
279603218.author: a TripAdvisor user
279603218.reviewBody: The cost was only 25 pesos. There is always a guide (student volunteer?) who can speak multiple languages. I visited in March 2015 and June 2015. Both time, the young guide was excellent! \nDon\'t forget to visit the next door , that has an exhibit for how the Cathedral was built, together with some religious paintings, old music scores, and priest roves.

277837527.name: Interesting but expensive.
277837527.author: a TripAdvisor user
277837527.reviewBody: Very interesting and beautiful, but what you see from the entrance gives you a general idea. We decided not to pay exuberant price for a twenty minutes of look around.

275161688.name: Lovely smell
275161688.author: a TripAdvisor user
275161688.reviewBody: The library -- hidden inside the Casa del Culture -- was nice to look at and had an amazing old-book smell, but we were quickly turned out to pay for the experience which, having seen how small it was, really wasn\'t worth it.

266159736.name: Great library!
266159736.author: a TripAdvisor user
266159736.reviewBody: The library is well designed and artistic. It has a great collection of ancient books. It is an immense wealth of knowledge stored here.

261009395.name: amazing place
261009395.author: a TripAdvisor user
261009395.reviewBody: It is the first library created in Mexico, it is an amazing place and worth the visit, must be seen if going to Puebla.

260555021.name: Stunning place
260555021.author: a TripAdvisor user
260555021.reviewBody: This library is just beautiful. it has some really interesting old books and the carved wooden interior is spectacular. Don\'t miss it!

257576892.name: Library
257576892.author: a TripAdvisor user
257576892.reviewBody: One if my favorite sites in Puebla.  I am a book lover so a 17th century collection was thrilling.  The building was great and the collection thrilling.

256441928.name: A unique gem in the Americas
256441928.author: a TripAdvisor user
256441928.reviewBody: It won\'t take you long to see this library but it is worth it given its historic value. Plus, it is charming.  Don\'t forget to go to the side rooms as there are some other things on display.

250815424.name: Beautiful and historic
250815424.author: a TripAdvisor user
250815424.reviewBody: Dating from the mid seventeenth century, this is the most beautiful library I have ever seen.  The woodwork is finely wrought, with an upper gallery to reach the higher shelves.  A number of old maps and globes are displayed.  It is small but exquisite...obviously a labour of love, the contents energetically sourced from the old world, and including then current volumes concerning New Spain.\nOriginal works of Isaac Newton, Rene Descartes, and most notably for a Bishop\'s collection, the scandalous work of Copernicus suggesting that the earth orbits the sun, not the other way around, as the previously accepted.

250685299.name: Awe Inspiring
250685299.author: a TripAdvisor user
250685299.reviewBody: This place was unbelievable and should not be missed. It is the library of a bishop who lived i here in 1646. The library is absolutely gorgeous with the original wood shelves unlike any you have seen; highly carved and polished. The many tables are all original as well. There are 43,000 volumes , some as old as 1455!  It is the oldest library in the Americas. It was the highlight of my sightseeing in Puebla.

249363931.name: The library was interesting
249363931.author: a TripAdvisor user
249363931.reviewBody: but the room next door that talked about the building of the church and had so many religious statues interested me more. All were included in the same price.

249165875.name: Stunning
249165875.author: a TripAdvisor user
249165875.reviewBody:
The library is located in one of the many beautiful buildings around the Zocalo in Puebla and a bit hard to find.
One needs to buy a ticket (rather cheap) from an office next to it and the guards are very helpful in explaining history and details of the library.

The design, details and books are stunning and absolutely gorgeous. Another must-see in Puebla.

248831107.name: Pretty
248831107.author: a TripAdvisor user
248831107.reviewBody: Well, its just this, pretty. and photogenic, you dont get to see many libraries as this one in Mexico. Its now awe inspiring, but its .. pretty. If you have seen a few of the best ones of the world I would avoid it, but if you are a simple mortal like us the rest, then visit it.

248529897.name: Great if you are into Books and Libraries, if not...
248529897.author: a TripAdvisor user
248529897.reviewBody: Look, this was interesting only because I like libraries and old books.  It is the oldest library in the Americas.  It is unfortunate that they charge to get into this exhibit.  It is not very big.  If you are not into books and libraries just skip it.

248317849.name: not worth it
248317849.author: a TripAdvisor user
248317849.reviewBody: It\'s just a room with sealed books.  Need tablets to explain the collection.  Cannot understand how the books can be preserved when there are windows with screens and no climate control.\n\nVery difficult to find.  Had to ask several people.  The exhibits in the cultural building attached, however, were very good.

246102803.name: Wonderful and atmospheric!
246102803.author: a TripAdvisor user
246102803.reviewBody: The Palafoxonia needs only 15 minutes to be visited and shouldn\'t be missed. It is the first llibrary in the Americas and houses an astonishing collection of books that are around 300 years old.

244736107.name: The oldest library in the America\'s
244736107.author: a TripAdvisor user
244736107.reviewBody: This library was built by an archbishop who was ahead of his time.  Most unusually it was open to the public without paying a fee.  The architecture is gorgeous and the collection of old books is impressive.  The library is small but fascinating.  It is worth hiring a local guide at the entrance  and you can pay him whatever tip you feel is appropriate.

243415519.name: Great building, watch the rest of the exhibitions
243415519.author: a TripAdvisor user
243415519.reviewBody: The Library is the high point in this beautiful buinding, beautifully carved wooden furniture to hold the impressive collection of books. There is a nice courtyard where they hold musical performances and some little known collections of engravings by famous artists from the revolutionary period.

242957878.name: Brilliant!!
242957878.author: a TripAdvisor user
242957878.reviewBody: When I saw this Biblioteca Palafoxina listed as one of the places to see before you die I planned a trip, fell in love with it with just seeing the pictures, you think "Wow, this place must be huge, it is the biggest and oldest library in Latin America". It is not as big as you may think, it is one single room, but in the end it didn\'t matter. It is totally worth it. The architecture is breathtaking!

242925409.name: Small place but must visit..
242925409.author: a TripAdvisor user
242925409.reviewBody: The historical value of the library is worth the visit, very well preserved. Beutiful perhaps unique woodwork, not a large inslatalation but it is very worthwhile.  Next to it is the Cathedrals treasures museum, quite new and also very worthhile.

242585520.name: A must see in Puebla
242585520.author: a TripAdvisor user
242585520.reviewBody:
Spend 1/2 hour there. 
Ask for a guide, you won't regreet it! 
They are very nice and love their job and the library.
Don't miss the "Museo de los Tesoros de Catedral"  (Treasures of the Cathedral Museum)
just next door -same ticket- very small and beautiful.

241163491.name: just Beautiful
241163491.author: a TripAdvisor user
241163491.reviewBody: If you are in Puebla, this is a must, it is the oldest Library in Latinamerica, you can see the beautiful architecture and books from 300 or more years ago, it is located behind the Cathedral, and you only pay 20 pesos.

239857879.name: Bibliotheque de palafoxiana
239857879.author: a TripAdvisor user
239857879.reviewBody: The house of the bishop of Puebla. This man was a book lover and I\'ve seen  some book of Isaac Newton, Descartes, and many other very old book. A must see.

239829652.name: Very Cool Attraction
239829652.author: a TripAdvisor user
239829652.reviewBody: While old books aren\'t really my thing, I was quite impressed by the quality and the history of this library. It is essentially one large room, but oh what a room. It contains thousands of books that are quite old. A lot of the original woodwork is largely intact and nice tables and chairs have been donated throughout the years. We took the English tour and had a great and informative guide who was studying to be a Spanish-English translator.

237668829.name: Hidden treasure oposite of the cathedral.
237668829.author: a TripAdvisor user
237668829.reviewBody: We had to ask directions, but in the end we encountered this impressive collection of books in a beautiful hall. Like time had been halted. It\'s small and a we had to pay a small fee to get in, but did not regret it.

236038300.name: Hidden Gem
236038300.author: a TripAdvisor user
236038300.reviewBody: Get the tour guide to tell you all the details and insights. The library is hidden in the back of the municipal building.

235491928.name: One of the best
235491928.author: a TripAdvisor user
235491928.reviewBody: This Library has one of the biggest collections of old books in Mexico, is beautiful building very well maintain where even today many students go not only to admire the book collections but to study because it keeps the tradition of a quiet place to study

230024793.name: Not a lot to see...but worth seeing
230024793.author: a TripAdvisor user
230024793.reviewBody: This site is not easy to find but if you love libraries it\'s worth seeking out.  It\'s just a block off the Zocalo and your visit will likely only take 10-15 minutes. \n\nThe woodworking and history of this spot are both very cool and something to marvel at.  It\'s only one big open three story hall and you can not touch any of the books, hence the reason why your visit will be short.

227792877.name: Nice, but not worth a detour
227792877.author: a TripAdvisor user
227792877.reviewBody: Mainly for those especially interested in libraries and book collections in Mexico. Good woodwork and old tiled floor. Basically one long room with books, for which you pay to peer at. The afternoon I visited, staff on duty were neither helpful nor informative and more interested in conversing amongst themselves.

226793724.name: fabulous library of old books and beautiful architecture
226793724.author: a TripAdvisor user
226793724.reviewBody: This library looks like a painting, but light filtering throuhg old windows onto polished wood and old books and manuscripts looked in cabinets covered with mesh wiring. Don\'t miss this.

223302273.name: Amazingly maintained
223302273.author: a TripAdvisor user
223302273.reviewBody: Just nice to see. They have books as early as the 1400\'s and are in perfect shape. the guides in there are super nice, do ask for their explanation, it just makes it more interesting.

221860236.name: Highlight of Puebla
221860236.author: a TripAdvisor user
221860236.reviewBody: This is an amazing cultural treasure.  Don\'t just go and peek inside.  If I had not gone through this remarkable library with the guide who came along with the extremely reasonable price of admission, I would have missed out on so much marvelous information and background about this oldest library in the Americas.

220939748.name: A great place to visit if you are at the center of Puebla
220939748.author: a TripAdvisor user
220939748.reviewBody: This library is a historic site for its time and size rare in the New World and quite impressive by any standards.

207758810.name: Gorgeous
207758810.author: a TripAdvisor user
207758810.reviewBody: A lovely library dating to the 16th century and built by Juan de Palafox, who brought with him 5000 books from spain. Its a must.

207630611.name: Palafoxiano library
207630611.author: a TripAdvisor user
207630611.reviewBody: a hist\u00f3ric landmark in M\u00e9xico and Latin Am\u00e9rica. The cuide gave an inter\u00e9sting Explanation, but only in Spanish. \n\nNo facilit\u00e9is for old or handicapped,  Written information nota available, no  orientaci\u00f3n for entrance

203325060.name: Well worth the visit!
203325060.author: a TripAdvisor user
203325060.reviewBody: Definitely worth it to have a guide walk you through the library.  Of course you cannot look at any of the books, but the history is fascinating, the architecture is splendid and you can just imagine the scholars sitting around the exquisitely carved table and chairs discussing pithy matters!

202648764.name: Interesting
202648764.author: a TripAdvisor user
202648764.reviewBody: Ask for the guided tour to really get the most of it. A voluntary tip is all you need to get it and it really helps to  understand why this library is a must see.

201594329.name: Don\'t miss this
201594329.author: a TripAdvisor user
201594329.reviewBody: This is purported to be the oldest library in North America and established in the 1500\'s. The wood work in the library is wonderful and the visually it is stunning. The oldest book in the collection predates Columbus reaching the New World. Located on the far side of the Cathedral from the zocolo. It is worth the short walk.

198316573.name: Amazing
198316573.author: a TripAdvisor user
198316573.reviewBody: First library in the Americas. Beautiful wood craftsmanship. Its really quite a site. A must see in Puebla.

197023737.name: kingdom public library
197023737.author: a TripAdvisor user
197023737.reviewBody: Was founded on 6 sept.1645,by Juan de Palafox y Mendoza,\nIt HAS MORE THAN 41 000 BOOKS,ranging from the 15th to the 20th century.\nit was listed on UNESCO\u00b4S memory of the world register.

195895899.name: Library par excelence
195895899.author: a TripAdvisor user
195895899.reviewBody: Possibly the first public library in the Americas.  A short visit but worth a look.  Great wheel for reviewing books in tandem.  For those interested in public learning and books this is a great place.

193885191.name: special place
193885191.author: a TripAdvisor user
193885191.reviewBody: We stopped by there to see the oldest library in the Americas. It was Sunday and they had cultural events in the courtyard. We saw a symphony orchestra followed by Aztec dancers. The audience seemed mostly local which was more special to us.

190985873.name: Worth the visit!
190985873.author: a TripAdvisor user
190985873.reviewBody: Though the visit can be short, its worth going to  see a 400 year old library. Though you may not touch the books, you can look closely at them and get a very good sense of their antiquity.

190180750.name: Fascinating library
190180750.author: a TripAdvisor user
190180750.reviewBody: Centrally located.  They give very good tours of library included in the price of admission (though they appreciate tips as well) that are definitely worth taking advantage of.

187219572.name: North America\'s 1st Library is a must see.
187219572.author: a TripAdvisor user
187219572.reviewBody: You have to see this beautiful building. What a rare treasure. Rich with history. See North America\'s first and premiere library.

185679346.name: a trip into the past
185679346.author: a TripAdvisor user
185679346.reviewBody: What an exquisite example  of a library from centuries ago!  Tucked in the corner of an old building, this remarkable, and well preserved, beautiful library will leave you marveling.  The books are centuries old, the talavera gives you an insight to the previous artistic styles, and the woodwork in the interior are some of the most incredible carvings I have ever seen.  It is truly majestic,  well worth a visit while you are near the cento historic.

176348520.name: Don\'t miss this one!
176348520.author: a TripAdvisor user
176348520.reviewBody: Our private guide took us to visit the Biblioteca.  Wow, it was incredible and we would have never known that it was there (You have to know where to find it).  Very interesting and worth a visit.

176224282.name: An exquisite library!
176224282.author: a TripAdvisor user
176224282.reviewBody: The oldest library in the Americas does not disappoint - beauty interior, texts, scrolls and books in the original Latin organization style. Perfect condition. If you love books and intellectual history you will need to see this.

174747423.name: Biblioteca Palafoxiana
174747423.author: a TripAdvisor user
174747423.reviewBody: You have to visit this library if books are important to you! It\'s the oldest library in its original place in the Am\u00e9ricas. Since I\'m a librarian it was heaven to me. You\'ll be amazed by the beautiful, original Talavera tiles and furnishings, not to mention the enormous collection of vintage works.

169375791.name: Awesome
169375791.author: a TripAdvisor user
169375791.reviewBody: Small but wonderful. Just by breathing near the books you feel they\'re gonna turn into dust. Some are 15th Century books.

168888326.name: Oldest library in Latin America!
168888326.author: a TripAdvisor user
168888326.reviewBody: It\'s super interesting and worth making the short visit. It\'s fascinating and, if you speak Spanish, the guards will answer all sorts of interesting questions about the library.\n

168609003.name: Quick Stop -- Make sure you visit this place.
168609003.author: a TripAdvisor user
168609003.reviewBody: Very unique place. It is a must if you visit Puebla. I didn\'t have to pay a fee to go in. There was a guide (Spanish only) available for quick talks for tips. It was very educational and unique. Pictures are not allowed but you can take a picture from the outside; the best shot anyways...

165094671.name: "... oh, the smell"
165094671.author: a TripAdvisor user
165094671.reviewBody: If you love books and how do they smell just as much as I do then you will love to visit this precious Library full of antique books.

162235763.name: Just see it through the door
162235763.author: a TripAdvisor user
162235763.reviewBody: Unless you find a good guide, do not pay the entrance fee which is a bit expensive and you can take a look from the door. I do not have a doubt that the books must be very valuable however you don\'t get to see them and it is frustrating.

160703519.name: Do not miss it
160703519.author: a TripAdvisor user
160703519.reviewBody: Beautiful with 45000 books from the 16th 17th and 18 th. Ask for David to guide you around. You will find this behind the Cathedral in the Palacio de la Cultura.

160090808.name: The Biblioteca Palafoxiana is a Must!
160090808.author: a TripAdvisor user
160090808.reviewBody: You will be amazed by the collection and the setting. This library holds thousands of priceless books on all subjects. It is quite a beautiful space loaded with treasures from centuries past. Well worth a visit, and it\'s just behind the Cathedral.

158250716.name: impressive
158250716.author: a TripAdvisor user
158250716.reviewBody: Cooler than it sounds like it will be, though why they do not allow you to take photos is beyond me.  It seems visitors are tolerated, not encouraged, so don\'t expect to be welcomed or given any information.  Still, it is amazing to walk around and ponder the changes that have taken place in the way information is exchanged.

157480863.name: One room library
157480863.author: a TripAdvisor user
157480863.reviewBody: You can stand at the door and see into the room without paying\nThat\'s all you get .... A one small room library

157341033.name: Interesting
157341033.author: a TripAdvisor user
157341033.reviewBody: Not as big as I expected but certainly worth a visit. We paid 35 pesos to get in not sure if it was worth that!

153771606.name: A must for bibliophiles
153771606.author: a TripAdvisor user
153771606.reviewBody: An incredible old library, dating back to the 17th Century, with books in it that are even older (1470\'s!). While the collection was started in the 1600\'s the shelves and furniture were built in the 1700\'s and are very well taken care of. It was astounding seeing all of these ancient volumes, including texts by Isaac Newton that were on display.\n\nIt was a bit hard to find: It is actually located in the "Casa de Cultura" (house of culture), and you have to go into the courtyard and up the stairs at the back to the second floor.

150617172.name: Oldest library in North America
150617172.author: a TripAdvisor user
150617172.reviewBody: A must for book lovers, at least.  It is pretty awesome to be in a library that\'s about 500 years old.  It doesn\'t take long to visit and it\'s right in the center of town so it should not be missed.

146558868.name: UNIQUE
146558868.author: a TripAdvisor user
146558868.reviewBody: The only preserved ancient library of ll the American continent, really deserves a visit. With only minor reforms (all of them introduced very long ago) this beautiful place remembers the library of Salamanca University, taken as model for it.

144109025.name: 450 year old books!
144109025.author: a TripAdvisor user
144109025.reviewBody: What can I say?  It was incredibly moving to see 450 year old books.  I only wish I could have turned a few pages.  The long sense of history was evident as we wondered beside and below the stacks of the oldest library I\'ve been in.  A short visit because the library was closing but then we enjoyed other exhibits in the same building.

141268152.name: A must see
141268152.author: a TripAdvisor user
141268152.reviewBody: One goes to look at one room really. But gives a glimpse a times long past. Very impressive with all its old books, tables and chairs. Definitely worth the visit

135776085.name: majestic sacro-religious assortment
135776085.author: a TripAdvisor user
135776085.reviewBody: bound books in parchment or leather.  The cases are locked with wire clad panes. Another example of the peripheral exquisiteness of Mexico. Constitute a finest collection. Located in the centro cultural.

131448636.name: its beautiful and it feels old
131448636.author: a TripAdvisor user
131448636.reviewBody: it can be a short visit but well worth the trip, make sure you get a guide.

130557318.name: They let us peep in but it was closed for a conference
130557318.author: a TripAdvisor user
130557318.reviewBody: In early May, Puebla is getting ready for the Cinco de Mayo celebrations and the library was closed for a conference.  Our guide asked if we could have a peek from outside but that was all we were allowed.  It looks magnificent but it was disappointing not to be able to take a closer look

129432448.name: Hard to get in
129432448.author: a TripAdvisor user
129432448.reviewBody: hard to get in, I literally had to cry so they would let me in....tried four times and always with some conference...All I wanted was to take a peak

128256382.name: Not to be missed
128256382.author: a TripAdvisor user
128256382.reviewBody: This library from mid-1600\'s is really incredible. Some books date back to the 1400\'s.

127269006.name: An unbelievably beautiful room with immense historical significance.
127269006.author: a TripAdvisor user
127269006.reviewBody: The Palafox library is on the second floor of the Casa de la Cultura, which is just on the other side of the cathedral from the zocalo.  Go on Tuesday, when it\'s free (although it\'s cheap other days, too.)  The entry and the library room (one long room with three levels of books) is so beautiful you wonder why we don\'t have more of them.  The books are very old and are not accessible, but then, you don\'t go to read, you go to see something that doesn\'t exist in many other locations.  I think it is a "must see" in Puebla, if only for 15 minutes (or more.)\n

126798320.name: If possible don\u00b4t miss it
126798320.author: a TripAdvisor user
126798320.reviewBody: If you are planning a visit to Puebla there are things that can\u00b4t be out of your list this Library is big and all the books are old, although you can\u00b4t take any book out I can\u00b4t imagine all the incredible things they have inside

126068985.name: magnificent
126068985.author: a TripAdvisor user
126068985.reviewBody: A library? really intersting? Really yes! Definitely worth the small price of admission. \nEntering this unique space is stepping back to an elegant era when craftsmanship was king. People are surprised at how fascinating the displays are. It\'s a wonderful space to wander through at least once.\nOutside the library, itself, there are usually interesting art exhibitions. Next door is the Casa de la Cultura, an especially useful tourist resource offering GREAT maps and the most useful tourist information in Puebla.  They also host some of the best performances - dance, music, etc. around town.

125931795.name: worth seeing - skip the fee
125931795.author: a TripAdvisor user
125931795.reviewBody: They charge for this library, however you can see all of it just from the doorway.  It\'s beautiful and worth seeing. great building.

124268934.name: Interesting place
124268934.author: a TripAdvisor user
124268934.reviewBody: This library with more than 40 thousand books is as beautiful as interesting. beautiful artworks and the whole atmosphere is breathtaking. Don\'t miss it!

123850095.name: Books, the foundation of civilization
123850095.author: a TripAdvisor user
123850095.reviewBody: an ancient library in a building with some other art exhibits and a performance space... a very old and quiet space-- I had it to myself--that leads to reveries of times past. And an old version of Windows: a set of book desks on a rotating wheel so you can have several books immediately available and open at once.

123781757.name: Possibly the oldest public library in the western hemisphere
123781757.author: a TripAdvisor user
123781757.reviewBody: For book and history lovers, this is worthwhile. Some of the oldest, most special books are on display. Though this is just one room, it is very special.

122641195.name: not to miss
122641195.author: a TripAdvisor user
122641195.reviewBody: The library was one of the places we visited in Puebla. It was really very impressive. In the building  you\'ll find also other expositions. The tourist office is in the same street.

118467577.name: The magic of books (and bookcases)
118467577.author: a TripAdvisor user
118467577.reviewBody: Some people dream of possessing flashy cars, mansions or jewels, others dream of having a beautiful library like the Biblioteca Palafoxiana in Puebla, founded in 1646 by Juan de Palafox y Mendoza. In the core of one of the most ancient blocks of colonial architecture, entering this library is like entering the heaven of books. This was the first public library in America and faithfully conserves its tradition of intellectual and cultural European heritage, with more than 41 thousand books and unique manuscripts; part of a selected collection extending from 1473 to 1821. The baroque room and the precious wood bookcases (on three levels) are just astonishing. It is in fact a jewel, which is why is part of Unesco World Heritage list since 2005. Unfortunately photos are not allowed, not even without flash. Why is that?

116939561.name: If you like books, don\'t miss it!
116939561.author: a TripAdvisor user
116939561.reviewBody: Very impressive, it smelt old book, love it!  If you love book, don\'t miss the opportunity to visit this place.  There is a special atmosphere!

22448365.name: An old fashioned library
22448365.author: a TripAdvisor user
22448365.reviewBody: This is the way a fancy classic old library looked. Lovely and it is inside (up the stairs) the Casa de la Cultura which is right behind the Cathedral. If you aren\'t into old books just have a free peek from the doorway or go on Tuesday when it is free to enter. The room is sometimes used for lectures. There is also a bit of a museum of old books but maybe it\'s only for special fans.

653960742.name: Magic
653960742.author: a TripAdvisor user
653960742.reviewBody: Out of this world... or full of this world! Ancient civilization ruins meet beautiful/outstanding landscape! When I went it was not super busy, which made it even better... dry season in winter, no one around... felt like a dream.\nCan\'t wait to go back

651271553.name: A hidden Gem!
651271553.author: a TripAdvisor user
651271553.reviewBody: At Cantona you will find a sprawling ancient city with many ball fields. It is a huge area to check out so be sure and wear good shoes! This site is amazing with the extent of buildings and temples. The giant pine trees that sway in the breeze and provide much needed shade are beautiful. Arrive early and allow yourself plenty of time as this site is huge! Take water and food as you can not buy anything except souvenirs on site!

651221567.name: Pyramids of a mysterious culture of uncommon proportions, city as important as Teotihuac\u00e1n with 27 "Ball Game" recints.
651221567.author: a TripAdvisor user
651221567.reviewBody:
Located on a very short ride from Puebla( 1 hour 30 minutes) you can drive through the highway to Xalapa, Veracruz. 

You would be able to visit one of the most important cities after the fall of Teotihuacán; design against the standards with multiple stone streets and 27 recints to practice mythic  "Juego de Pelota" ( " Ball game").

You will find a small museum with the main pieces found in the excavation, brief history of the people whom use to live here ( from a civilization still unidentified between Olmecas, Mixtecos, etc). There you can fin also bathrooms and a souvenir store.

Be aware this site closes at 5 pm and , on my opinion, is not recommended for limited movility due high, tall, ancient stairways are impossible to walk around or access with a wheel chair. You can walk slow with safe support points.

I would recommend up to one hour visit and be welcome to return because site is too long for one visit. Make sure to get enough water , you may have the chance to buy one at souvenirs store, yet it won't have enough for a full bus , on my opinion.

You will find a convenience store with a yellow and red stripes on the highway, small town close to the pyramids won't be my recommendation for lunch, it would be better to have a small detour to Huamantla, larger and more interesting city. 

Enjoy!

637527047.name: Beautiful, interesting, it is really worth it visit!!
637527047.author: a TripAdvisor user
637527047.reviewBody: It is located around 90 minutes driving from Puebla, the road is beautiful, the landscapes, everything clean. The archeologic zone of Cantona is very big, I thing we walked around 3km at least, I really liked it! It is really impressive, it has a small museum. I think this is a really good place to visit!

630770301.name: Hidden archeological jewel nearby CDMX and Puebla
630770301.author: a TripAdvisor user
630770301.reviewBody: M\u00e9xico amazes me every time I travel through it. All the territory is full with natural, historical and gastronomical places that make every trip worth the visit. This time is the turn of Cantona to take the stage. Although it is not on the usual archeological path for most tourists, it is certainly located in one privileged hill. From the top of the complex you can see in all of its splendor Pico the Orizaba. But attention need to be placed on the ruins themselves. These are ones of the best kept pyramids in Mexico. From the bottom of the hill they look small but once you walk through the cobblestone paved corridors (which date back to when these pyramids were originally built some centuries ago) that lead to he main complex you can advert the scale of this city. It runs for a couple of miles. Unluckily we did not have the time to walk it all. Any serious tourist in the area should take the time to visit them. Besides, they are on the way to Xalapa 10 minutes from the highway.\nThe best / worst thing is that they are unknown so there are no visitors even on the weekends. Don\u2019t miss them!

542274327.name: A glimpse of the past!
542274327.author: a TripAdvisor user
542274327.reviewBody: These archeological ruins are very well worth the visit.  Even though just about 1% of the zone has been unearthed, the site offers a very nice two and a half hour walk in the old city of Cantona, with lots of history behind.  This city was a very important commercial center, a necessary stop on the way to the coast and to the central plateau in Mexico.  Get a guide to tell you about its interesting past!

503701228.name: Great Surprise
503701228.author: a TripAdvisor user
503701228.reviewBody: Visited the Cantona Ruins in Puebla on our way to Coatepec Veracruz for the weekend.  I have lived 3 years in Tlaxcala / Puebla and never heard of them before.  It was a worthwhile trip.  Located at around 10 minutes from the Highway Toll toward Perote the Cantona Ruins are composed of a series of walls, pyramid bases and indigenous soccer fields (over 16) that housed over 70,000 people at its time.  Not many people know about this place which makes it very peaceful.  The whole walkthrough took 3 hours.   There is allot of information through the roads but it is best to pay a tourist guide and support the local people.  Bring a hat, lots of water, sun glasses and lotion to avoid sun burns.  Enjoy!

481662145.name: Cantona Mexico\'s Machu Pichu
481662145.author: a TripAdvisor user
481662145.reviewBody:
I have been to Chichén, Coba, Tulum, Teotihuacan, Machu Pichu, all of these magical and amazing and with tourism to justify their status, Cantona is no different and doesn't fall short in any way when compared to any of these other cities. 
The place is magical beyond belief and when you finally reach the top of the citadel and look around you, only then do you realise the magnitude and greatness of this place. Why this place is not visited by more people is beyond me. 
Access from the city of Puebla by car is approximately 90 minutes. The site itself is clean, well looked after, the museum on site is small but gives you a good idea of how Cantona came to be. If you want a guide it's best to go on a weekend. 
There is no other city like this in the Americas.

471237078.name: Pre-hispanic ruins unlike any other
471237078.author: a TripAdvisor user
471237078.reviewBody: This pyramids are like no other I\'ve seen in Mexico. The site comprises a large area of terraces and platforms with a few pyramids and, unexplainably, 25 ball-game courts!!!\nThe structures are fairly rustic made of volcanic rock with very few carved stones (mostly kept in the adjacent museum) The setting is arid with a great view of the Citlaltepetl volcano. Not easy to get to but the site is very well kept with fairly good trail signaling.

461181927.name: Cantona
461181927.author: a TripAdvisor user
461181927.reviewBody:
Probably took around 90-100 minutes or so from San Pedro Cholula but it's good road the entire way and almost all of it is highway. I'd guess it's maybe 15 minutes less if you leave from Puebla's Centro Historico.

We spent about 2 to 2.5 hours exploring and we didn't see all of it. It is huge! You initially go through an area where families lived. There are patios with stone platforms. Originally there were houses made out of wood, topped with thatch roofs, on those platforms but those disappeared a millenium ago. You walk uphill on what was a main walkway. There are walls on each side of the walkway but at the beginning they are fairly low since locals have taken some of the stones to use in other constructions. But the walkway goes uphill so the walls are taller the further you walk.

After a rather steep climb up - again, it's original walkway so we were careful with our footing - we arrived at the non-residential area with a whole bunch of pyramids.

It's a loop walk and the way back wasn't too difficult. It even had the occasional railing to hold onto. It's a metal railing and it was warm to the touch on a cloudy and cool January day. You'd need oven mitts to touch it on a sunny summer day.

I recommend wearing good shoes and a wide brimmed hat. It was fairly cloudy when we went so we got away without sunscreen but I'd bet you'd usually want to have some. Bring plenty of water and some snacks might be good, too.

There's a museum on site and we visited that first. Nice museum (and clean bathrooms). I think it cost 50 or 60 pesos to enter. And it's open on Mondays. Most of the info is only in Spanish but they do have summaries that give you the gist of the info in English.

453918433.name: Unusual ruins in a very attractive setting
453918433.author: a TripAdvisor user
453918433.reviewBody: These ruins are quite spectacular as they are quite different from others I\'ve seen. They have lovely walled walkways, striking vegetation and wonderful views. There is a nice little museum you can visit before climbing up to the ruins. Once at the top, you can really get a sense of the scale of what this city must have been like. As other travellers, I do recommend a visit here. It is about 1 hour and 1/2 by car from Puebla, so easy to get to. If you want to spend the night nearby, try Hacienda Tepetlcalli.

452239688.name: Awesome ruins!
452239688.author: a TripAdvisor user
452239688.reviewBody: Like most of the reviews here, we were super impressed by these ruins! They are expansive, in great condition, and in a beautiful setting. We only saw three or four other groups the whole time we were there...which is really nothing given the grand scale of the complex. Guessing that it will get more crowded as the word gets out, but it\'s not really in the travel books yet. And it\'s not super easy to get to. We took private transportation while we were going between Puebla and Coatepec and this was a perfect stop along the way. Note that some of the rocky steps were a little tough for a few of the older people in our group. Give yourself at least a few hours to walk the full complex. Be sure to bring some water along as well. Enjoy!

435683955.name: Should be much better known
435683955.author: a TripAdvisor user
435683955.reviewBody:
We only knew about Cantona because of the reviews here.   I'm so glad we went.   

Most Mexican ruins all that's left are the major temples, here you can see the layout of the streets, what private family properties were like and more.   

There are more than 25 ball courts, the most in Mexico.  There are over a hundred temple complexes.   

It's a fascinating place and the explanations are well done in both English and Spanish.   There are routes through laid out through the town to pass through the various parts, with tablets throughput to help you understand what you are seeing.  

The museum is modern and well done.  The labels are in Spanish, but a lot of supplemental info in English.   

You may have the place to yourself, we did.   

It's a unique place from a unique culture. Well worth the time to get there.

432742789.name: Magical place.
432742789.author: a TripAdvisor user
432742789.reviewBody: The ruins are so very different than other ruins we have visited in Mexico. One truly gets a sense of what life was like.  There are never many visitors and in the quietness it is easy to hear the noises of life from long ago.\nThe ruins open at 9AM.  We wanted to go early so we stayed at the hotel almost directly across from the ruins.  Hotel is a vague term.  When we asked for 2 downstairs rooms - the hotel was empty - we were told that people had the keys in the village for security??  no idea.  Actually the room was clean and ok. No hot water, no TV, no Internet and at nite only an older man sleeping the the office.  I would have loved a cheap plastic chair to sit and listen to the quiet and see the stars. The restaurant lady told us we were too late - 5PM and no way would she come any earlier in the morning - she arrives at 9 and slowly things will get done.  There is an OXXO at the tollway off-ramp.  We had to pay 33 pesos to get there and 33 pesos to get back but it was worth it since between the OXXO and the Pemex we found a great restaurant owned by a man from Perote.  Perote was settled by farmers from Spain and they are are famous for the smoked meats.  At the restaurant we had remarkable spanish tortillas of egg and potatoes with Jamon Serrano.  Also the white bean soup with smoked sausage is incredible.  Great hot chocolate! They also sell the ham and sausages.  Do plan on a meal there.  We filled out thermos with some very nice coffee for the next morning.

431839899.name: Awesome Undiscovered Place
431839899.author: a TripAdvisor user
431839899.reviewBody: This vast ancient city lasted longer than most so was maintained longer.  The whole area still has city streets and walls with many home platforms as well as larger temples.  All in a beautiful natural setting with mountain backdrops.

431439126.name: A special place in Oaxaca
431439126.author: a TripAdvisor user
431439126.reviewBody: I did a daytrip by public transport from Oaxaca in order to see this place. The place is huge, and because of the vegetation and surroundings, it is very unique. Would definitely recommend going there!

422157536.name: This was one of my favorite places
422157536.author: a TripAdvisor user
422157536.reviewBody: I visited in February of 2016 on a Saturday and the ruins were all but deserted.  It is so large and so beautiful. Make sure to wear comfortable STURDY shoes or sandals as you will be walking and climbing on stone and through rocky soil the entire time you are here.  The Mexicans are so respectful of their treasures:  we saw no caretakers or park officers yet the place is immaculate and the grounds well cared for.  The buildings, walls and pyramids at this locale used no grout between the stones and rocks; everything was fitted together perfectly.  Even though the excavated site is so large, most of the city still remains buried. If you visit, make sure you bring water and something to eat.  You are in the middle of nowhere and while there was an ad hoc food stand at the entrance while we were leaving, my digestive tract was not that desperate to risk another bout of MR.  \n I really would like to visit this site again if I am ever in this part of Mexico. It is a very peaceful, quiet, and contemplative site.

420275681.name: the guides and museum were unforgetable at the piramides
420275681.author: a TripAdvisor user
420275681.reviewBody: history really tells a story of mexicos past\nThe well kept and administered ruins were impressive and interesting.

418963489.name: What everyone says is true about Cantona
418963489.author: a TripAdvisor user
418963489.reviewBody: It is huge, beautiful, out of the way and a wonder as to why more people don\'t visit it.  It is laid out so that the paths wind you through every-day housing, plazas for Markets, neighborhoods and finally to huge temples that went on and on.  I only remember seeing this kind of density in the Mayan Ruin of Becan.  This was much larger in scope, but equally dense.  the number of ball courts was impressive and the design intriguing.  I wish we had hired a guide for the day, but none were there hanging out waiting for us to hire.  I imagine you would hire one out of Puebla, Cholula or Tlaxcala.  We stayed a good 3 hours at the site.  I climbed all but one temple because I was finally worn out.  It was a good visit and it left us wondering why it isn\'t promoted more.  We only stumbled upon it accidentally.  Easy to get to when you drive from Puebla to Veracruz.

402881096.name: Huge!  Simply astounding!
402881096.author: a TripAdvisor user
402881096.reviewBody: Having lived in Mexico City for a few months now we have had the opportunity to visit MANY pyramids in the area.  If you have the time (3 hour drive from CDMX/ 1.5 hours from Puebla) you absolutely must visit Cantona.  What Teotihuacan is to height, Cantona is to expanse.  It was surprising how much ground Cantona covers.  Each pyramid you climb shows you 2 more that you haven\'t climbed yet!  We went on a Sunday and I was surprised by how few people were there.  Bring a hat, sunscreen, your own water, and a snack.  Be prepared to climb some steps - all said a done, by FitBit said I climbed 41 flights of stairs that day.  Well worth the visit!

401840259.name: great place for archeology junkies
401840259.author: a TripAdvisor user
401840259.reviewBody: This place was beautiful but  get a guide as there is a lot to see. We where there in March so it was reasonably warm especially in the sun. The actual grounds are quite expansive so be prepared for a good deal or walking. The walking is generally flat with limited amount of stair unless you decide to climb some of the structures. The admission price from what I remember,  was reasonable.

377991695.name: Must see if you like ruins
377991695.author: a TripAdvisor user
377991695.reviewBody:
I've always been a huge fan of old archeological ruins: Greek, Roman, Mayan, Incan, English,- you name it. One of the biggest surprises of our trip to Mexico is how rich the country is in world-class ruins. While Teotihuacan (also a must-see) gets the press, there are dozens of other fantastic, under-visited sites. If you are like me in enjoying wind-swept, remote, romantic, mysterious, empty ruins- you must find a way to visit Cantona.

What makes it unique: unlike other sites like Teotihuacan and Cholula, Cantona was primarily a commercial city, so what you see is more like Pompeii than it is like Egypt- you see the streets and housing layout across a huge area of this high desert terrain. It's also built on mountainous terrain so you have an excellent feel for how and why they laid out the city the way they did. The huge site is worth several hours of walking and during that time we only saw one other group- a group of students who we only ran across once. The rest of the time was all to ourselves (note that we were mid-week, which might have made a difference).

I would definitely recommend a guide- we visited with Carlos Rivera who was excellent, There is a small museum but otherwise very few signs and explanations- you could use your imagination and still enjoy it, but probably better with a guide- especially because you'd need a car to get there.

376482347.name: Amazing place to visit!
376482347.author: a TripAdvisor user
376482347.reviewBody: This is a must do when around the area. It is one of the most amazing places I have visited. You are literally walking through what was once a city. It is hard to believe how big and old this place really is. We were contemplating going because it is about an 1.5 hour drive from the zocalo in Puebla, but we are so glad we went. \n\nWe left Puebla around 8:30am and were one of the first few people there. Be sure to take your own water to last about 2.5 hours. There is minimal shade so be prepared for sun and moderate rocky trails with incline. We made it to the end of the trail in about an hour with a few stops along the trail. It is in a very remote location so a private car makes the journey very easy. We paid 2000 pesos for the round trip and the driver waited for us.

375140082.name: Among the Best Archeological Sites in Central Mexico
375140082.author: a TripAdvisor user
375140082.reviewBody: A trip to Caltonac (Cantona\u00b4s true name) takes a couple of days. We stayed at a gorgeous boutique hotel located nearby in Tepeyahualco (Hacienda Tepetlcalli Hotel Museo & Spa 1870). The museum, although small houses a collection of Caltonac artifacts worth seeing. About five minutes away is Cantona. Visiting the Caltonac Archeological Site takes at least a full day, because it is a large urban setting built by the olmeca-xicalanca culture. There you can fully appreciate one of the highest degrees of urbanization in ancient times. It is said that the urban area covers about 70 km2. The ruins include a road network of over 500 cobblestone streets, more than 3,000 individual patios or residences, over 24 ball games and an elaborate acropolis with many ceremonial buildings and temples.

370373358.name: a must see
370373358.author: a TripAdvisor user
370373358.reviewBody: if you are into archaeology at all don\'t miss this place.  it is massive.  wear good shoes, hiking boots cause the terrain is hilly, walking on cobblestones or dirt trails, lots of steps, pyramids.  it is a hour and half drive from Puebla but worth it.  the ruins are massive, the scope of the city can be seen from on top of pyramids.  the skill it took to build this site with no cement, stones stacked on stones is truly amazing.  the museum is small but worth the visit.  it has artifacts found on the site, recreation of the homes the people lived in here.  bring your own water and lots of it cause you cant get it there.  there are no restaurants around either so plan on doing it after breakfast,

361344556.name: Great Ruins
361344556.author: a TripAdvisor user
361344556.reviewBody: We really enjoyed touring these ruins in the Puebla area. At this time, they are being renovated to help you understand how it was to live there when they were made.  We found it to be very interesting.

360180968.name: Impressive, well preserved, off the beaten path
360180968.author: a TripAdvisor user
360180968.reviewBody: These ruins are huge! You can walk for hours from pyramid to pyramid and from ball park to ball park. It is very well preserved and in contrast to other sites not at all touristy (although they have also a museum). I have been to Tulum, Xitchen Itza, Palenque, Teothihuacan, Tula, and other places but this is certainly on of my favourites. Very quiet, good condition, and helpful archaeologists.

354899401.name: Insuperable haunting ruins
354899401.author: a TripAdvisor user
