354899401.reviewBody: The largest city in Mesoamerica after the fall of Teotihuacan, solitary and beautiful setting, majestic succession of ritual ball game courts, not as high as Teotihuacan\'s pyramids, but so beautifully spaced and architected in uniquely majestic successions of spaces and higher buildings in terraced layers. An amazing example of urbanization, all of it built without cement . Go slow if your knees are not the best!

349554411.name: amazing place to visit, despite the tricky public transport situation
349554411.author: a TripAdvisor user
349554411.reviewBody:
Firstly, all of the glowing things reviewers have written in the past about Cantona are true - it is utterly breathtaking!

A few tips from my experience:- 

- go earlier in the day rather than later (for reasons which will become clear further down)

- allow yourself lots of time as the site is huge and the altitude is 8,200 ft (2,500m)+. So if you're not fit you'll need to take your time going up & down the many many large steps on the site

- take plenty of water and a hat, as the site's altitude & wind means the sun is deceptively strong and the air very dry & thin; there's little shade onsite too

- take your own food, as there even though there is a museum at the site entrance, there is no cafe or even vending machines and no shops until Tepeyahualco, the nearest village, 8km away (and not IMHO walkable).

- public transport options are not for the fainthearted, esp solo female travellers!  If there are more than 2 or 3 of you I'd seriously suggest you look into hiring a car for the day, as it's much quicker and less stressful - it took me 3h 45mins each way by public transport, and I didn't wait a long time in Oriental for connections either way.  I really don't understand why there are direct bus services running from Puebla to Cantona!

Here's my advice on how to get to Cantona from Puebla by public transport.  Please don't let this put you off!  It's just I hope if my experience can make anyone's else's a little easier, all the better! :-  

1) take a bus to Oriental run by 'Via' bus company from the CAPU bus station in NW Puebla.  I took a taxi from where I was staying near Zocalo which cost 60 pesos and took 20 mins (although note it wasn't in rush hour).  I'm sure there are buses running to CAPU too, but no-one at the Tourist Info office could tell me which/when/where(!)

2) there is a Via bus ticket office to the right as you enter the main CAPU hall.  They weren't over-helpful and it was lucky I spoke Spanish as there was no Spanish (it was the same in the Tourist Info office too).  They will ask you to confirm what service on which you want to return from Oriental.  This is tricky as the mini-van services from Oriental to Cantona don't run to any kind of timetable!  So I was sold an open return (70 pesos x 2 + taxes), but the man checking tickets before we got on the bus at CAPU said this wasn't possible and I'd have to book a definite service once I got to Oriental.  When I got to Oriental they said no that's fine, its a new type of ticket.  However I had the same problems on the way back (although I was eventually allowed on the bus, thanks to a very helpful female Via member of staff at Oriental.

Note that CAPU has plenty of food outlets to stock up on, and several public toilets.

3) the bus to Oriental is quite comfortable and takes about 1hr 40 mins.  There is no toilet onboard.  There are several stop before Oriental, and no announcements: Oriental isn't the last stop for the service, so it is worth asking the driver to tell you when you reach the right stop in Oriental as there isn't a recognisable bus station (I nearly missed the stop because of this!).

4) there isn't a bus service as such from Oriental to Cantona.  Instead there are white minibuses ('combos') which are shared between several passengers.  They don't run to any kind of schedule - they just wait until there are enough people.  I was misdirected as to where the combos where, and was a bit annoyed to find after walking 20 mins around the town in the midday heat that there was a pick-up point literally 2 mins walk further down the road from where I got off the Via bus from Puebla!  Look for turquoise building just after the Via ticket - the white minibuses wait on the corner just after that.

5) the minibus journey from Oriental to Cantona took about 40 mins, and cost 30 pesos.  The bus makes several stops (all on demand from passengers) in small settlements between the two locations.  Try to agree a return pick-up time at Cantona to go back to Oriental with the driver - although note that doesn't mean they'll turn up! (see below)

6) the journey back from Cantona to Oriental is, in short, partly the lap of the gods!  I paid for & agreed my return journey, but the driver didn't turn up: I was lucky after waiting another 25 mins another combo turned up, so I took that one.  I was talking to one of the guides and he said even though the site is open until sunset, after 5pm very few combos come up to the site, and it is quite common for drivers not to turn up even when agreed in advance.  There's no mobile signal at the site, so you can't even try to call a combo/taxi.  The nearest village is Tepeyahualco, 8km away (and not a walk I would ever want to do) but I'm not even sure there were taxis there - I certainly didn't see any.  So that's why I advise you go to the site earlier in the day, as there are more combos running and you're not at risk of being stranded if your booked combo doesn't show up.

7) note that the combos will drop you off at their waiting area in Oriental, and the stop for the Via bus back to Puebla is on the opposite side of the road to the Via office.  The Via office has a toilet, but there is little seating.

Enjoy!

333110821.name: Outrageously large complex of Ruins
333110821.author: a TripAdvisor user
333110821.reviewBody:
Cantona is magnificent in every way from the physical infrastructure that still remains (to the vastness of what was once and is lost) without a knowledgeable guide and with alcoholic beverages one could become lost among the remains - HIRE A GUIDE, it is Mexico, they are not expensive! 

The very small town of Tepeyahualco has the most lovely ex-Hacienda Hotel you will find in small town Mexico.  The master of the kitchen will prepare the most amazing dishes for you or your group.  Cantona / Tepeyahualco are approximately 45 minutes outside of Puebla, I recommend planning the trip in advance around the holiday or holy time as this small Hacienda will not be available unless you are planning 2 seasons in advance.  

All parks offer free entrance on Sundays in Mexico! USE THE GUIDES (even on Sundays) They work from tips only.

328110849.name: A must if you are in Puebla
328110849.author: a TripAdvisor user
328110849.reviewBody: Getting there is not that straightforward but don\'t let that be a problem! If you are staying in Puebla, you take a bus to Oriental (Via is the company). Once in Oriental you have to options: take a taxi (ask the price before getting in) or a colectivo (approximately 35 MEX). You\'ll need about 3 hours to visit the place.

315977388.name: beautiful setting
315977388.author: a TripAdvisor user
315977388.reviewBody: I loved this ruin. My favorite in central mexico, prefer it to teotihuacan, cacaxtla, or xochicalco (they go on that order though.)  The setting is really what makes this place excellent. It has a few big pyramids (probably in the 60-80 feet tall range) but lacks the height of teotihuacan, the carvings of xochicalco, or the art of cacaxtla. When you are on top of the pyramids of cantona, you get an idea of how big this city was (probably 80-100 thousands people) and get some excellent views of a volcano. As the site is so highly elevated, you get some Joshua tree looking plants and a heavy pine presence, so it\'s very peaceful. Worth 2-4 hours. I went with a guide, Carlos Rivero, and he took my gf and I to cantona and cacaxtla ruins in one day, highly recommend that tour, two great spots, all day though from puebla.

315595787.name: Out of the ordinary side trip from Puebla
315595787.author: a TripAdvisor user
315595787.reviewBody: It ios a walk from the Central Plaza to the Ruins but well worth it . On the way there visit the several Art Galleries

313741729.name: Worth the trouble
313741729.author: a TripAdvisor user
313741729.reviewBody: On a cloudy and threatening day I made it to Cantona, after several mishaps along the way. Hotels are scarce and I was tempted to keep driving and forget the visit. I decided to pay more than I wanted to and checked into the hocienda nearby. Then I made the 15 minute drive to the archeological site. It\'s an impressive entrance once you park, and the impressions continue. The site just goes on and on and gets better and better. I recommend dong the longer tour and mounting the last pyramid. The view is amazing.

308785880.name: Secret Gem Nearby Puebla
308785880.author: a TripAdvisor user
308785880.reviewBody:
This place is the largest ruins I have ever been including Ephesus in Turkey. I mean we spent one hour in museum and one and half hour just walking around the old city and we still could not finish it. We probably covered 2/3 of the opened area. According to what they say, only 1.5 percent of the area has been opened and the rest is still underground.

We drive there with our rental car and it took us about 1 hour 15 minutes from Puebla downtown area. We arrived there early in the morning. We were the only visitors and we did not see anyone in our 2.5 hour visit, which is very nice. We got special attention from museum guide who also spent an hour with us describing everything in Spanish (my wife translated me).

Entrance fee is about 55 pesos but since we are student they did not take any money from us.

I suggest you to bring some snacks and water because we were really hungry and that's why we left a little bit early and was not able to cover the whole area but 2/3.

I suggest you to go to museum first and then take the walking tour around the pyramids and ruins.

This place has a very important part in the history of Central America, you should definitely spent at least 3 hours to be able to enjoy the whole archeological site.

306345337.name: Possibly the most stunning ruins in Mexico
306345337.author: a TripAdvisor user
306345337.reviewBody:
I must echo all these other reviews and say that this is indeed as stunning and unforgettable as it has been previously described. This is so so worth a full day trip from Puebla if you find yourself there.

What is most amazing is the fact that so much of the residential and living quarters of the city has been excavated, unlike other sites in Mesoamerica like Monte Alban or Teotuhuacan, This gives it a much more ghostly and magical feeling, as you start to get a sense for the lost world that we know so little about still (despite the excellent but small site museum giving a good overview of the existing knowledge of the Cantona people). 

This place is seriously huge, you keep climbing up pyramid after pyramid and seeing more and more of the site lay out before you. At the very top and tallest pyramid, the view of the windswept high plains with endless miles of unexcavated city criss crossing the landscape is nothing short of magical. I went on a Sunday, which is probably the most crowded it gets, and I counted 11 other visitors in the entire 3 hours I was there, which adds to the magic.

Bring a picnic and water, as I don't believe either are sold at the site.

Getting there without a car is a bit of an adventure, I took a bus from CAPU in Puebla to the little town of Oriental, where I then hired the one taxi driver in town (the very friendly Jose Felipe) to drive me to the site, wait for 3 hours, and return for 270 pesos (around $17 USD, which was very much a bargain). I probably could have spent much longer, and I'd definitely consider staying a night in either Oriental or the gateway town of Tepeyahualco to do so.

Don't miss this site if you're in central Mexico, this is up there with Macchu Picchu and Angkor in beauty.

305798536.name: Cantona.
305798536.author: a TripAdvisor user
305798536.reviewBody: Unique archaeological site in Mexico because of its location and because you can see small street (like in the picture) and on each side small "house" for the prehispanic people. In Cantona, they found 27 pelota games areas. There is also a small museum before you begin the visit. May have a hat a sunblock (sun is strong...). The view up is gorgeous.

291810451.name: Deep relaxing atmosphere
291810451.author: a TripAdvisor user
291810451.reviewBody:
It was my first time seeing pyramids in México and I didn't know anything about it. 
When we arrived there and just see stones it was some kind of boring. But as more we walked into the area some kind of peace and silence came over us. You are far away from noise and lots of people and it is a beautiful landscape. We sat down somewhere just enjoying.
I will always come back here.

You can walk several paths/ tours and the longest can take three hours. I would recommend good shoes!!! And bring something to drink with you.

288357478.name: Great Time
288357478.author: a TripAdvisor user
288357478.reviewBody: This place is in the middle of knowhere.  There are no restuarants, vendors, nothing.  The pyramids are very nice and restored.  Very few people.  The \u00e1rea of the pyramids is very large.

286944943.name: the cholula piramid is the biggest piramid in mexico
286944943.author: a TripAdvisor user
286944943.reviewBody: this place use to be a very rligious place for the ancient cholultecas people , so when the spanish came they cover the piramid with soil and build a church on top

277077530.name: Impressive really good restaurated arqueological location.
277077530.author: a TripAdvisor user
277077530.reviewBody: Nice small museum. Good preserved area to walk around up and down. Get\'s a little exhausting at heat and in high air. But is worth the work.

273717559.name: Amazing
273717559.author: a TripAdvisor user
273717559.reviewBody: It\'s got quite a history, it\'s funny how hidden and unkonwn it is. It takes a while to get there from Puebla and the road feels dangerous, everyone drives it too fast. Once you get there you get to feel and listen to the wind like nowhere else. It\'s stunning, I loved it.

259960180.name: An amazing place
259960180.author: a TripAdvisor user
259960180.reviewBody: It was very easy to get there from Puebla and well worth the trip. It takes a bit of energy because the site is extensive and you go up and down steps and pyramids. The route is well marked and there are  boards explaining what it\'s all about. It\'s easy to see the areas where people lived which is unusual.

259022046.name: March 2015 update
259022046.author: a TripAdvisor user
259022046.reviewBody: This is a do-not-miss if you want to see something totally unique, special, and mostly untouched by tourists. Previous reviews tell how incredible this place is. I will add what I did not see before: This site is built up to side of a large hill/small mountain. Every section is terraced so you do quite a bit of climbing. At every turn there are new vistas, ceremonial plazas, pyramids, ball courts. There are lots of signs (in English) explaining each important area so we felt no need for a tour guide. The route is very clearly marked. You can go three different length loops. The first will tale 1-1.5 hours, the second (a continuation of the first) will take 2-2.5 hours, the third (again a continuation) will take 3-3.5 hours. We took the 2.5 hour loops and time flew by. We could have gone on to see the rest. In the distance we saw two other people the whole time. The museum is finished now and is beautiful, well lit, and new and shows many items mentioned in the trail signs. It 55 pesos to get in the site. NOW: To get there, that is the trick. We spent 2 days asking around Puebla. We decided we just did not want to go on public transportation (too much time involved). At the tourist info center (north side zocalo) we went to the desk on the far right. They offered tours at 550 pesos per person with a four person minimum; or you could pay the entire 2,200 pesos and have the tour to yourselves..This included up to 8 hours and an English speaking guide. We offered them 1,800 pesos for just the driver (we did not need the guide) and only a total of 6 hours. They accepted our offer. Our driver, David, knew enough English to explain things we passed. The drive on the toll road was under 1.5 hours. On the way back we took the longer route but saw several small villages with beautiful churches, a saltwater lake made by a meteorite, and endless cactus gardens. We spent 2.5 hours touring the pyramids (hard to call this beautiful city ruins) and were back at the zocalo 6 hours after we left. No photos I have seen even begin to do Cantona justice. Trust all the great reviews and see a place you will try to tell your friends about.

255959466.name: One of the top archeological sites in Mexico
255959466.author: a TripAdvisor user
255959466.reviewBody: It is a wonderful site with well preserved buildings which give you a very good idea of this earlier civilization.  There is a new highway (with tolls) that can get you there in about 1 hour 45 minutes.  We could not find any tours or buses and the main taxi terminal wanted to charge us almost 3000 pesos!  Instead, we asked the taxi driver who took us to the hotel if he would do it, and he charged an hourly rate of 200 pesos.  All in all, the trip was 6 hours. Bring good walking shoes as the rocky paths need firm shoes, plus, of course being water.  We ate a simple quesadilla and beans at the restaurant across the street for $4.  Anyway, don\'t miss this site if you are in Puebla or Cantona!

254188600.name: EXTENSIVE SITE
254188600.author: a TripAdvisor user
254188600.reviewBody: This site is about 90 mins out of Puebla; extensive walking and climbing. You need a hat, water, sunblock, and lunch. There is a very nice museum to see prior to visiting the ruins. It was a thriving city with many housing complexes and narrow streets until about 1100 AD. If you are interested in pre-Columbian runis this is a must see.

252059541.name: Cantona Arquelogical Ruins
252059541.author: a TripAdvisor user
252059541.reviewBody: ruins in a beautiful setting with great views. A real must in the region. These ruins are not yet very known so you don\'t meet with too many tourists

244461732.name: Rough walking, but worth the trip
244461732.author: a TripAdvisor user
244461732.reviewBody: Very interesting site.  You will walk a lot on rough streets, but the site gets more interesting as you progress.  Plan a couple hours here as there is a lot to see if you are interesting the archaeology of the area.   One of better archaeological sites in central Mexico.

238834643.name: Can\'t really add anymore...
238834643.author: a TripAdvisor user
238834643.reviewBody: ...brilliant site as others have said. The only thing I can add is it took us over 2 hours by taxi to get there (we agreed on price before we went), it was quite chilly (early November) so rug up and you should allow 3 hours to see the place.

228547038.name: A wonderful place, an archeological site out-of-the-ordinary
228547038.author: a TripAdvisor user
228547038.reviewBody:
When you visit Cantona, you should be prepared for an archeological site quite different from other in Mexico. The first thing that cacht my eye, is that Cantona has pavemented streets with rocks, all the archeological site that you walked on pavemented streets. The other thing is that there are no temples devoted to any Gods, it is a city with buildings and the perimeter of the houses which are made of rocks, and you can see the design of the interiors, that's because the walls were made of Wood. 
It is very big, it takes 2 to 3 hours of walking the site.
To get to Cantona you should drive from Puebla to Perote and exit in Oriental, there are signs to Cantona.
If you want to stay, there is an old Hacienda in Oriental.

224341424.name: Wow, awsome!
224341424.author: a TripAdvisor user
224341424.reviewBody: If you are interested in precolombian Mexico (and even if you\' re not!) this place is worth the trip. 1h30 drive from Puebla, it is not as famous as other sites (Teotihuacan for instance) and certainly not as crowded, but fascinating: you will walk 2-3h long in ancient streets and restored pyramids; you end up at the top pyramid that gives you a 360\u00b0 view on what this huge city was (only 10% excavated yet). It is easy to figure out what life was in that time for its 100 000 inhabitants who left for a reason still unexplained. A guide is highly recommended. A small museum at the entrance is worth visiting prior to the walk in the city. \ndon\'t forget to bring walking shoes and some water.

223531690.name: An unexpected surprise
223531690.author: a TripAdvisor user
223531690.reviewBody:
Arqueological sites are the favorite places I like to go whenever I travel, I´ve been to all of the major Arqueological Sites in México. 
When I heard about this place I had no idea what to expect. I entered the site and walked for a couple of minutes until I got to where the pyramids were. When I got there, I took some pictures and noticed I could go up to "the top of a pyramid".
When I got to the top, I saw an entire set of structures with of course, another pyramid I could climb.
I repeated this action a few times, this place was huge!
Another thing I loved was that it wasn´t deteriorated, the structures seemed intact. This is my favorite arqueological site in all of Mexico, and I´ve been to Teotihuacan, Palenque, Tajín, Chichen, Itzá, and many more.
If you go, walk all the way to the end and enjoy the unbelieveble view.

221694176.name: Incredible place
221694176.author: a TripAdvisor user
221694176.reviewBody: I hadn\'t heard of Cantona until it was recommended to me by someone who lives in the area. It\'s astounding. The surrounding countryside features mountains but also dried lava and yucca (?) trees, so just driving to Cantona (from Xalapa) was spectacular. At the ruins themselves there is almost no one who isn\'t working there (excavation is ongoing). I saw just one group of people in more than two hours. The route to walk along is clearly marked and takes you through ancient streets, past (and sometimes up) pyramids, and through ball courts (the winner got to be sacrificed). It takes at least two hours to do, and more if, like me, to want to take pictures of every lizard and every view. The place is huge, almost empty, and beautiful. There\'s also a great little museum, mostly in Spanish but with almost miss-able sets of boards or cards hanging from pegs with English information on them. If you can get here to visit then you absolutely should.

212105136.name: ruins very different from anything I have seen
212105136.author: a TripAdvisor user
212105136.reviewBody: As mentioned before, the site of Cantona is very very large.  It is so different because visiting here is visiting a town not the ceremonial centers of a civilization.  The walking is difficult so I didn\'t see near half of it, but I was entranced.  The walking tours go down what would have been the "streets" of the village.  The walls are in excellent condition.  To take the long trip is about 4 to 5 hours.  I was there for about 2 and saw a lot and very much enjoyed it.  The day we went was cloudy - there is not shade so be prepared.  \nThe museum is excellent and worth your time.  Such a big place and few visitors makes for a magical experience.   $48 entrance fee

207759136.name: Fantastic Ruins
207759136.author: a TripAdvisor user
207759136.reviewBody: Amazing ruins, not quite Chichenitza or Paleunque, but definitely worth seeing. An hour and change away from Puebla. Make sure you hire a translator at the visitor center in Puebla and ask for El Cooper (short for cupertino), when you get there. He is a great guide.

205419065.name: An relatively unkown beauty near Tepeyhualca
205419065.author: a TripAdvisor user
205419065.reviewBody: I was really astonished and surpised by the beauty of this place. It is a large very old city very well structured on a small hill. Dozens of pyramids, structures of houses and playgrounds for pelote from this period. It is an amazing place to visit that definetely left a big impact on me.\nI was the only visitor walking around on friday afternoon. If you intend to go here, stay in Tepeyhualca at the Hacienda Tlepticalli hotel Spa 1870 and you will even more be pleasently surprised about this area. I talked to my friends in Mex City about this place and none of them new it.....,they will all be going now for sure

197433904.name: Worth a day trip
197433904.author: a TripAdvisor user
197433904.reviewBody: This is a large, somewhat mysterious archaeological site.  There are dozens of small and medium -sized step pyramids, and numerous ball courts, altars, and walkways, in addition to large expanses of living areas marked by low stone walls or rubble fences. None of the structures individually match the impressive size of, say, the pyramids of the Sun or the Moon at Teotihuacan; but this is a very different site. As you follow the walking trail into Cantona, you climb onto hills that are covered with the ruins, and progressively wider vistas open around you.  This was once a city inhabited by 90,000 people, according to the descriptive text in the site museum, and it must have been a teeming hive of activity.  Now, when you climb to the top of the highest hill on the site and take in the stunning view of the ruins below and the dusty plain and mountains in the distance, all you\'ll hear is the wind...\n\nWe visited on a Thursday and stayed for about three hours.  During that time, we saw seven other tourists and three employees; in total, ten people scattered throughout the site.  If you\'re driving here from Puebla, it seems easiest to take the toll road route 150.  We took the free road route 129 and had some problems finding our way.  As of March 2014, the access road running between  Cantona and route 150 is well-paved. You don\'t need to drive down any dirt roads.  The site museum seems new.  It is small but informative, and most of the major displays have English translations available.  Spending half an hour in the museum is an excellent introduction to this unique place.

195815701.name: Really nice landscapes ropund the ruins
195815701.author: a TripAdvisor user
195815701.reviewBody: This is completely off the standard touristic trips so you will have them all for yourself. You can clearly see all the streets from the city and the view at the end is really amazing. Worth a trip and it is just 70 km from Puebla.

191283559.name: a little-known treasure
191283559.author: a TripAdvisor user
191283559.reviewBody: Cantona is one of the best-preserved, biggest and most interesting archeological sites I\'ve ever been to. It\'s a bit out of the way, but easily accessible even if you\'re using the bus/collectivo system. I cannot believe that this site isn\'t more famous. My husband has been to Machu Picchu and thought Cantona was equally amazing -- he actually liked it better because there were so few people around.

172430106.name: THE Pyramids to go to if you are near Puebla.
172430106.author: a TripAdvisor user
172430106.reviewBody: Cantona is one of the best pyramids I have ever gone to. They are located about an hour and a half away from Puebla in a very remote road near a remote village. On your way there you will notice there is one small sign near one of the big highways and that is it so just stay on the road and you will get there, somehow. Once you arrive you have to pay a very small fee for entering. The route begins at a "main" street with a couple of what could have been houses. You continue walking and see more and more pyramids with fantastic views of the valley and Pico de Orizaba. Make sure to take the full route to see the last pyramid where you can truly see how vast this site is. It is said only 10% of the site has been explored. Don\'t miss this place you will be amazed.

135564277.name: Great mountain views, expansive site, great natural flora
135564277.author: a TripAdvisor user
135564277.reviewBody: Have been here twice, most recently in May. Archaeologists think this is the biggest pre-Colobian site in the Americas. They have only excavated about 10% of it, and it takes easily 3 hours to check out in its entirety. The site becomes more dramatic as you get deeper into it. It starts with a long raised stone "street" of sorts, which connected many different living quarters. You begin to note that this really was a city, with streets and houses one after another, densely populated, not unlike a city today. After a brief but steep climb, you get to all the ceremonial and ritual areas. Here there are at least a dozen different ball courts and even more pyramids, one after another after another. They also increase in size. When you get to the far end of the site, you are graced with an expansive sweeping view of the Pico de Orizaba, a beautiful semetrical volcano not far away. Also in the foreground is the rest of the site - unexcavated, covered in cactus. It is not hard to imagine, seeing the small rocky hills - whcih are pyramids - how enormous this place once was. On the way back (you take a loop), you pass some of the biggest pyramids of all and a few grand squares. It can get quite hot out there, and there is little shade, so I recommend bringing water. The site has just a bathroom, a kindly old man who watches your car (please tip him) and a person who charges the minimal entrance fee, though the last time I visited the parking lot attendant said the museum contructed there was about to open. I was told this as well when I visited the site two years prior; we shall see when it actually opens. Anyway, a great undiscovered gem. You won\'t see stucco paitings or intricate carvings here, but pure grandeur of quantity and size of construction, as well as beautiful cactus filled surroundings and unobstructed mountain views. Hard to get here without a car. Could be combined with a trip from Puebla to the beautiful mauntain town of Cuetzal\u00e1n, which is about another 2 or 2.5 hours away by car.

120924702.name: Cantona with view to the Pico de Orizaba
120924702.author: a TripAdvisor user
120924702.reviewBody: Cantona overlooks a wide valley with a salt lagoon and on good days you can see until the Pico de Orizaba.\nMake a picnic in the wide area. There is anyway no restaurant, only a little shop. Take the old rout to Puebla and have an icecream at the "villa", that is where the railway line corsses the street. Its delecious

116826762.name: An Unforgettable Experience
116826762.author: a TripAdvisor user
116826762.reviewBody: I heartily agree with the other reviews. We managed to find a guide to take us here as we were somewhat underwhelmed with Puebla. It\'s about an hour away in a pretty remote area. The ruins uncovered thus far are nice if somewhat smaller in scale than others, but the setting! Cactus covered fields, snow covered mountains in the distance and it is unusually quiet for Mexico. For most of our visit, the three of us had the place entirely to ourselves! How often does that happen? If you are in Puebla for any reason, it will be well worth your trouble to find a way here.

96728198.name: Every bit as impressive as the other better known ruins in Mexico
96728198.author: a TripAdvisor user
96728198.reviewBody:
While staying in Puebla my wife and I made a day trip to Cantona about 90 km NE of Puebla more-or-less using public transporation. 

Although generally not described in travel books, the site is very impressive and unfortunately does not receive many visitors. For almost all of the 3 hours that we were there on a Friday, we saw no one else. 

From down town Puebla, here is what we did.

-taxi to CAPU bus station
-"Via" bus line to Oriental - about 70 peso each and about 90 minutes on local highway 129.
-exit the bus in "centro"
-taxis were right there
-"chartered" a taxi to take us to Cantona, taxi stayed for 3 hours (it takes more-or-less 3 hours to walk the site) then return to Cantona.
-english speaking guide (he spent 1.5 years in Calgary and his English is quite good) lupevasquez@live.ca  
-"Via" bus back to Puebla from Oriental centro - at an estimated 30 minute intervals.
-total door to door time - 8 hours - total cost about 1,000 peso

The site is much different than the well descibed and well visted Monte Alban, Teotiuacan, and Chichen Itza, etc, with many comparatively low pyramides and many ball courts on a quite large site. 

For a group of 4 persons, hiring a taxi for the day in Puebla would probably make more sense, since the bus fare for the two of us cost about 300 peso, and would have the advantage of going by the faster toll highway.

92420372.name: WOW!
92420372.author: a TripAdvisor user
92420372.reviewBody:
We went to Cantona Archeological site on a Sunday trip with my family. It is about an hour from Puebla with a very good road. 

We were impressed that this site is not as "popular" as others in Mexico. The place is gigantic, very well maintained and is different than many other sites in the country which makes it very interesting. 

I definitely recommend you take the tour if you are in Puebla.

83376742.name: Cantona Magica
83376742.author: a TripAdvisor user
83376742.reviewBody: I have to echo the previous review on Cantona. I operate bicycle trips in the Puebla/Veracruz area and have brought people to the ruins many times. There is something special about this site that goes beyond just the details of the excavated architecture. Perhaps it is strange, dry hills surrounding the place or the eerie quiet of the excavated ball courts. Most of all I love it because there is almost never anyone else there. A far cry from the throngs crawling over Chichen Itza, the light shows at Uxmal or Sunday at Teotihuacan. Probably a little tricky to get there by public transport but doable and very easy if you have a car. Great place to stop on your way to Cuetzalan but that is another story.

16443757.name: Visit Cantona in Puebla
16443757.author: a TripAdvisor user
16443757.reviewBody: When we started researching about where to go in the state of Puebla, the name of Cantona popped up. We asked our guide about it, but he was not enthusiastic or elaborated about the place. Our mind was set and we wanted to go, Cantona was described as an archeological site and we were interested to learn. When we got there our jaw dropped, there is no way I can describe the place with words, it is a newly "discovered" site and only about 1% has been excavated, it is a city with different and well marked social strata. There, you can find guides, local people with deep ties to the site, that for a tip($) can explain what has been discovered and help you use your imagination to picture what is still there, don\'t think for a minute that it is a small site, no, it is thought to be one of the largest urban areas in mesoamerica, so prepare for a good trek and climbing of pyramids.

647609179.name: PUEBLA\u00b4S PRIDE
647609179.author: a TripAdvisor user
647609179.reviewBody: It is one of the military forts were the famous battle between the armies of Mexico and France took place on May 5th 1862.  The Mexican army defeated the French army.  The fort was built in 1816. Currently there is a museum inside.  Surrounding the Loreto Fort there is a large and very well maintained park where you can walk, run, ride a bike, there are also areas to eat.   Nearby are other museums and the planetarium, all located within the same park where the Fort is.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

629109982.name: Nice
629109982.author: a TripAdvisor user
629109982.reviewBody: A little bit overpriced and is closed in low season. Nice view of Puebla from here. You can also walk around.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

614236600.name: Nice panoramic view
614236600.author: a TripAdvisor user
614236600.reviewBody: For this fort you can have a nice panoramic view of Puebla city and also arrive in a park very nice, clean and quiet.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

600871089.name: Great view.
600871089.author: a TripAdvisor user
600871089.reviewBody: Los Fuertes Is a mandatory place to visit if you are in Puebla.\nYou can find a observatory here and some restaurants. I really enjoy the ride in the cable railway.\n

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

595701254.name: Where Cinco de Mayo Happened!
595701254.author: a TripAdvisor user
595701254.reviewBody: The Loreto Fort is an impeccably maintained walled fortress, with cannon parapets and a central headquarters building within. The fort is high over Puebla, and provides a great view. This is where General Zaragosa executed the attack on the French invaders that is so widely celebrated in the U.S. (and Puebla) as Cinco de Mayo. If nothing else, you have to stand on those parapets and become one of the very few Americans who have any idea where Cinco de Mayo originated. There is a very interesting museum within the headquarters building, wbich will provide all the background you can absorb. Take a Uber or cab up to the Fort from downtown--from the Centro, a Uber costs maybe $5.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

591752332.name: Nice view
591752332.author: a TripAdvisor user
591752332.reviewBody: This a small fort overlooking the city. A small museum is inside that gives a brief history the Cinco de Mayo battle. (Note that the fort didn\'t play a roll in the battle.) Good view. A small cafe is below the fort and is also a good spot to rest and catch the view.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

588108229.name: Very historical place and nice surroundings
588108229.author: a TripAdvisor user
588108229.reviewBody: Very historical place and nice surroundings, including views, gardens, buildings: WTC, Exposition and events center, Puebla funicular.\nGovernor residence nearby

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

563164050.name: Very important battle in Mexico\'s history, a must see for any lover of history
563164050.author: a TripAdvisor user
563164050.reviewBody: The Battle for independence which Mexico fought against Napoleon III\'s French army in 1862,  which they were victorious by the way on May 5 1862, gave birth to their national holiday "Cinco de Mayo", which is a major holiday celebrated by Mexicans every where on that day. It occurred on this hill in Puebla at these 2 forts. It wasn\'t on our tour list, so we grabbed a cab bright and early one morning and away we went. Cabbies in Mexico are very nice and patient, he waited around and shined his Taxi while we walked around at both monuments Fuerte Loreto bottom of hill and Fuerte Guadalupe top of hill, of course the museums weren\'t open, so we took our pics, and when we were done, he took us back to our hotel. Total fare less than $10 US, what a bargain

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

558586769.name: Nice park
558586769.author: a TripAdvisor user
558586769.reviewBody: It\'s a beautiful park and the forts are interesting but I think I would rather have spent more time in town.   The forts are pretty small and it\'s a park that you could see in may cities all over the world.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

558169909.name: take a nice walk while discovering Mexico history
558169909.author: a TripAdvisor user
558169909.reviewBody:
a must stop while visiting the city!!

It's a really nice place to pass the evening and part of the night walking around the park while learning about the history of Puebla. Both forts have good material including weapons, documents and uniforms. they offer guided tours ideal for people who look for deeply understanding of history.

Both forts offer a unique panoramic picture of the city and the gardens are ideal to.hang around with your partner, friends or family!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

555884916.name: You need to walk around and know its history
555884916.author: a TripAdvisor user
555884916.reviewBody: This place has been improved in the last year\'s and I think it worths it. There are a lot of activities you can do there with your friends, coup, family. During the night the view of the city is really nice.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

551269477.name: the ACTUAL 5 DE MAYO
551269477.author: a TripAdvisor user
551269477.reviewBody: Forget about all th myths and legends. The Battle of the 5th of May actually took place in the surroundings of this fort, in 1862. The French Army was defeated for the very first time in history. Victor Hugo wrote a heartfelt letter to Puebla despising Napoleon III and declaring his friendship to the Mexican town.... History live!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

549458610.name: Great place to walk to from Zocalo
549458610.author: a TripAdvisor user
549458610.reviewBody:
I take a minimum hour walk daily and this turned out to be perfect. Get a map at the tourist office on the ZOcalo and try to find your way to the main street De Los Fuertes and walk up. 
Great views from up there and fresher air.

I did the first fort Fort Loretto and at 50 pesos entrance fee it was ok but a bit run down.
It was OK though. I like the old military history.

This fort I do not believe had any direct action in the CInco De Mayo battle but was a backup or something.

Anyway walking up to the main fort was a bit difficult to find (or my alzheimers was hitting hard that day) and upon arriving a young man approached me spitting out costs and discounts for seniors or kids etc. I said thanks but Im not Mexican and so the discounts dont apply. Then I started to walk towards the main walls to see the view before going in tothe museum and he started telling me I could not do that I had to pay first. So based on his attitude I just said great thanks and turned around and walked away. 
You can get the view outside of the fort as well.

By the way the whole trip walking was more than double my normal one hour. But wonderful day for weather and great views up there. So well worth it.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

547922183.name: Nice museum in an old fort
547922183.author: a TripAdvisor user
547922183.reviewBody: This fort has an exhibit regarding Mexican History and the battles fought with the French arouns cinco de Mayo. Part was closed due to the recent earthquake. The whole area is a large park with a great view of the city. But it is a long walk from the Zocolo area.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

546128597.name: Historical
546128597.author: a TripAdvisor user
546128597.reviewBody: We like to walk so we walked from Centro Historico to the Fuerte. It gives you an opportunity to more of the city up close by walking through various barrios. The fuerte is small. There are several portraits, an interesting mural, replicas of uniforms, etc. Some of the history is in english. You can take photos without a flash. There is a small entrance fee. There are good views of the city from the ramparts.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

524853139.name: Agradable ambiente e historia
524853139.author: a TripAdvisor user
524853139.reviewBody: It\'s a beautiful place, with lots of security given the proximity to governant\'s residence. Perfect for resting, walking and breath fresh air. If you enjoy walking or running then it\'s a great place to do so. On top the history of the place and the energy you can feel there is just a gift. Beautiful!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

509368623.name: Touristing
509368623.author: a TripAdvisor user
509368623.reviewBody: This spot is great for touristing around Puebla. There are some museums near and you can have a nice walk around

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

498662272.name: The old and new styles merged into one
498662272.author: a TripAdvisor user
498662272.reviewBody: This place offers history, arquitecture beauty, nature and a terrific panoramic view of Puebla city. The just renovated gardens are amazing worth walking and visiting.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

488664958.name: A fort is rather a misnomer
488664958.author: a TripAdvisor user
488664958.reviewBody: As you might expect this is quite high and if you walk there is quite a steep hill to climb. The fort is a bit of a disappointment though - nothing much there. We just took a photo from the outside and did not pay to see inside!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

476526730.name: A Historic Fort
476526730.author: a TripAdvisor user
476526730.reviewBody: If you want to know about Cinco de Mayo, this is the place to go.  The fort is fun to walk around, and the museum describes the events leading up to the battle and the battle itself very well.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

467352958.name: A fascinating location, with a poor museum
467352958.author: a TripAdvisor user
467352958.reviewBody: This is where 5 de Mayo started. What should be an exciting museum about the battle that gave rise to one of Mexico\'s most iconic holidays suffers from poor museography. A good part of the museum is dedicated to the Virgin of Loreto; there is a huge mural that seems to commemorate the surrender of the city to the French a year later rather than the battle; inaccurate captions and made up costumes do not help. On the other hand, the regional museum, the views and some of the other attractions are definitely worthwhile.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

454550803.name: Hilltop views worth the price of admission
454550803.author: a TripAdvisor user
454550803.reviewBody: Two museums actually, with separate modest admission charges, the relatively new museum at Fort Loreto at the lower, more westerly end of the ridge and the somewhat older Fort Guadalupe museum about a half mile further east at the top of the hill. Both forts were central to the Cinco de Mayo, 1862, fighting against the French, and to a lesser extent involved in 1863 French siege. For the cannon freak (me), there are 10 or so guns at Loreto, but only three at Guadalupe. Otherwise, both house interesting artifact collections. They both provide great views of the city and of the three active volcanos in the distance.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

444900336.name: Amasing Christmas decorations and view of the city
444900336.author: a TripAdvisor user
444900336.reviewBody: Amazing Christmas decorations and view of the city.\nCoffee restaurant on site has very nice ambiance, but service was lacking.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

443175351.name: Enjoyed the museum and the surrounding park
443175351.author: a TripAdvisor user
443175351.reviewBody: The museum was interesting and there was plenty of information in English that provided a good overview of the May 5th battle, what led up to it, the aftermath and the role that the fort played. The entry fee was a reasonable 50 pesos. The park outside, in front, across the street was green and peaceful. It had a pond with ducks, a shop with interesting items for sale, a nice cafe where I had a cold chai tea that was very good. I took the lower path to the left of the museum and was impressed by the many models portraying aspects of the battle and the war. This path lead to another cafe. From there I headed toward the Fuerte de Guadeloupe, about a half mile walk through the park.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

435572823.name: Fuertes de Loreto y Guadalupe.
435572823.author: a TripAdvisor user
435572823.reviewBody:
I have been here twice now and on my first visit, I did not get so se much, and on my second visit I was able to see much more and also tour the museum which is just full of history and just a beautiful site over all, and the fort has so much history.

Phone: +52 222 234 8513
Ejércitos de Oriente S/N, Los Fuertes,
72270 Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, PUE, Mexico

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

430605032.name: Historic fort atop hill in Puebla
430605032.author: a TripAdvisor user
430605032.reviewBody: Site of the famous battle of May 5 against the French expeditionary forces. Lovey view of the city below.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

427750072.name: Cool place
427750072.author: a TripAdvisor user
427750072.reviewBody: The museum isn\'t very interesting to itself, but I really enjoyed wondering around the fort. Plus the surrounding is great. Cool park, good views of the city, and not too far from a street with colorful murals. A refreshing change from the cento historico where we spent most of our time.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

427070880.name: a lot of history
427070880.author: a TripAdvisor user
427070880.reviewBody: This places hold a lot of history, since the battle with France, inside there is a museum, you must see it if you like history

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

426163740.name: 5 de Mayo
426163740.author: a TripAdvisor user
426163740.reviewBody: Must see attraction. If you are interested in the battle of puebla and the history you should be there, that way you will understand how Mexico was able to win one of them most important battles in history.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

424810851.name: A beautiful park with very nice views
424810851.author: a TripAdvisor user
424810851.reviewBody: Make a day of this one. There are museums. The two forts are very nice. There is a lot of up hill walking unless you get dropped off by a taxi at the top. This is what I would recommend so that you work your way down by starting at Fuerte de Guadalupe and then down to Fuerte de Loreto and the museums.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

420503636.name: Nice stroll to the park
420503636.author: a TripAdvisor user
420503636.reviewBody:
Scenic views
Nice sign where you can take photos with the city in the background
Windy!
There's a couple of small cafes so you can eat light snacks and buy water. 

Lots of families come here to play

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

408079333.name: Loved exploring
408079333.author: a TripAdvisor user
408079333.reviewBody: We really enjoyed exploring this area. My kids loved the paddle boats and walking down the bike trail to see the statues in the park. We saw the fort and got a picture with the Puebla sign too. Very nice afternoon.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

405585462.name: desecration of history
405585462.author: a TripAdvisor user
405585462.reviewBody:
the fort was subject to a horrible "restoration" that was neither correct nor necessary. The area around the fort keeps growing into some grotesque commercial park rather than make an effort to preserve the site in its original condition the day of the battle that was critical in preserving the Mexican Republic, as well as the US Union.
With all the additions the fort is obscured and encroached by trees that are not native or existed at the time, buildings that are irrelevant and a collection of the beautiful floats used in previous years during the 5 de Mayo parade. These in turn are not being maintained and begin to show the lack of care as they deteriorate.
there is a pretend museum inside the fort that is totally devoid of any real sense of history. The museum is a collage of religious, political and military element devoid of any coherent history. The displays seem to have been assembled by amateurs who know little or nothing of what is being displayed and the explanations of some of the items are plan shameful as they take away, rather than provide knowledge. 
the guides we overheard have no idea of what they are taking about, much less the relevance of the battle, in its own context, or in the larger geopolitical context of history.
Puebla is a great place to visit, with hundreds of beautiful museums, talavera, architecture, culture, restaurants that showcase Puebla's unique and wonderful cuisine, and great love and pride on the battle of 5 de Mayo. Thus, it is a real wonder that they seem to be set in ruining what should be jewel in the crown with no sense of historical preservation and better sense of the value -if not as a place to teach real history- what could be a world class tourist attraction similar to Gettysburg, and not the cheap afterthought it is today

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

394936008.name: The forts of Cinco de Mayo fame
394936008.author: a TripAdvisor user
394936008.reviewBody: These forts are certainly worth visiting while in Puebla. Not only are they famous for the battles that made Cinco de Mayo famous, but there is an incredible museum on the history of Puebla. Also gives you a panoramic view of the city of Puebla.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

394845142.name: What a great place to visit!
394845142.author: a TripAdvisor user
394845142.reviewBody: We didn\'t get to see it all, lots to see in Puebla and we only had one day but we did skim this attraction, WOW, 3-D history at it\'s best, so interesting and really captivates the young (and old) and delves into the history of 5 de Mayo.  The Battle of Puebla, where the Mexican army defeated the French under General Zaragoza....a must see, and I heard it lights up at night...wish we could have stayed to see that.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

393123693.name: Shame i got there too late for the full tour
393123693.author: a TripAdvisor user
393123693.reviewBody: Its a beautiful place with a great view onto the city-a really great reminder of the history of this place and the city.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

387845199.name: Back in time
387845199.author: a TripAdvisor user
387845199.reviewBody: you will see the amazin protection forts when the 5 de mayo fight was fought against the French army in the state of Puebla. dont forget to take your picture with the PUEBLA giant sign

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

382691237.name: Great historic insights in a calm environment!
382691237.author: a TripAdvisor user
382691237.reviewBody: Gave a really good overview on the history of Mexico and 5 de Mayo - something we don\u00b4t learn about where I\u00b4m from! The fort was well preserved and lies within a nice quiet park. Good place to get out of the city rush! We walked up there from the Zocalo, which is a \u00b1 30min walk. Otherwise you can take a cab, bus or one of the hop on hop off buses.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

382481100.name: Such a story and history
382481100.author: a TripAdvisor user
382481100.reviewBody: This is very worth a stop. This has beautiful views of all of Puebla and it is so rich in history. I think this park / area is one of the better kept secrets (until now) for tourists. You will see mostly locals here.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

380987739.name: Great place!!
380987739.author: a TripAdvisor user
380987739.reviewBody: Highly recommend it for families with kids. There is huge playground, museum of natural history, parks. We really like it!!!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

358497622.name: Good if you are history buff
358497622.author: a TripAdvisor user
358497622.reviewBody: I enjoyed the visit to the fort but the walk through the park and the views from the top of the hill were the true highlights. The Battle of Cinco de Mayo was not real big but still interesting to know.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

346143718.name: Must-see place
346143718.author: a TripAdvisor user
346143718.reviewBody: This place has been restored and improved and has the best look of the city. It has a small lake (man-made) where they perform some films during nights, parks, an auditorium and museums. Recently it has been put to work a cableway: although it\'s small it gives you a nice view.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

338156359.name: Prepare to see a lot
338156359.author: a TripAdvisor user
338156359.reviewBody: There is a lot of history in this area. Check out the interactive museum of the Battle of Puebla. During the winter holidays there are all sorts of light displays and mini replicas of many events that took place. Also there is a convention center and they are opening up more attraction. The huge flag of Mexico has the names of generals who were important to the Mexican revolution.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

332665473.name: EVER WONDER WHY 5 DE MAYO IS A HOLIDAY?
332665473.author: a TripAdvisor user
332665473.reviewBody: The forts at Loreto and Guadalupe are only part of what is available in this large public park.  You can also visit a High Tech Interactive Museum (free to the public) that will explain, in Spanish, the history of the Battle of Puebla on 5 May 1862.  The forts each have a museum charging a small fee to enter.  Displays are in Spanish and English.\nThe INAH Puebla Cultural Museum is also nearby on the same hill.  This museum has displays of artifacts from Mexico\'s early pre-history on through to the Spanish Colonial period.  There are also newer temporary displays of local artists and artisans.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

318979736.name: excelent historic place to visit where you find the history of Puebla
318979736.author: a TripAdvisor user
318979736.reviewBody: this place is a musem and was the place where the battle of 5 de Mayo of 1962 took placce against the french army , its a complete museum and very nice \u00e1rea to spent the day

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

317302382.name: Beautiful Overlook of the city
317302382.author: a TripAdvisor user
317302382.reviewBody: Since the entrance fee to the actual fort was like 45 pesos, but free on Sundays, we\'ve decided to come back another time to explore the actual fort. But the surrounding paths and overlooks of the city are quite beautiful and fun to explore - all for free. There is a really nice bike/walk path with various sculptures and models.  Surprisingly, under the wooden floor boards there is an artisan shop and a Punto del Cielo cafe.  \nAt the bottom of the hill is a pond where you can rent a paddle boat. There was also a sign that said during the months of October and November:  the Concordia Lake comes alive in this nightly sound and light show with special effects. The story of the magical towns and the most important monuments of the city of Puebla will be recounted on a huge screen of water. Thursdays-Sundays at 20:45 and 21:30.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

298506120.name: Worth the effort
298506120.author: a TripAdvisor user
298506120.reviewBody: Great place to spend part of the day. There are exhibits, things for the family to do and a cafe to relax and enjoy the view.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

296911326.name: History, a view and a great walk.
296911326.author: a TripAdvisor user
296911326.reviewBody: When you plan to go to Loreto\'s Forts, make sure the weather will be friendly for a walk, the museums are small but interesting, the forts are really well taken care of, with english explanations about what really happened in 5 de Mayo and why this city is called Puebla de Zaragoza, you can get inside the forts and then have one of the best views of the city, then as you go out, the whole area is good for walking and get your daily exercise, many green areas, a nice souvenir shop and cafe walking down the Loreto fort with view to their baseball stadium a little lake where you can pedal-boat, then go up to the next fort, to the planetarium, to the small anthropology museum, the green areas,theReforma auditorium, the musical fountains with kids bathing on them.. all in all a day filled with things to see. 5 stars!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

291811555.name: Best viewing point in Puebla
291811555.author: a TripAdvisor user
291811555.reviewBody: I\'m not interested in the fort but we come back here several times a year to enjoy the best view in the night over the city Puebla.\n\nThere is a kind of a walking path and you can walk a little bit. During the day you can find a coffee and a nice fountain on top of the hill. Also there are BBQ places for free. Many Mexicans enjoy it there. We too...

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

284381139.name: Helps Americans understand Mexican history
284381139.author: a TripAdvisor user
284381139.reviewBody: Unfortunately many Americans believe that Cinco de Mayo is Mexico\'s Independence Day.   Great English explanations for those who have limited Spanish as well.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

273717363.name: Beautiful
273717363.author: a TripAdvisor user
273717363.reviewBody: It has the most amazing view of the city. It\'s amazing, great for a walk, picnic, coffee, lunch, or just staring.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

267174565.name: 5 de mayo happen there
267174565.author: a TripAdvisor user
267174565.reviewBody: They are two fortifications Loreto and Guadalupe, in this area was where the 5 the Mayo battle took place. Ignacio Zaragoza was the general that won the battle, but the main issue is that the Zacapoaxtla Indians were the ones that really defeated the French army. The Indians weapons were only machetes that they used to cut sugar  cane in  the mountains telling the complete history oh what happen there will take me a  lot of time, but visiting these are of the city can give you an ide of what happen there in 1862

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

266607895.name: Good history lesson
266607895.author: a TripAdvisor user
266607895.reviewBody: The fort is OK to see, the building itself isn\'t very interesting to look at. There is a fantastic view overlooking the city, not sure if you can see the volcano from here as it was too hazy the day we visited. The reason I gave it a very good instead of just average is because the site museum has great signs with a lot of interesting history in both Spanish and English.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

258497802.name: Totally worth!!
258497802.author: a TripAdvisor user
258497802.reviewBody: I was surprised and impressed by this place. It has great architecture, design and urban planing.\n\nDon\u00b4t miss it...It\u00b4s great to go for a walk, to lay down on the grass and read a book, go for a boat ride...This is a great place to drink a coffee, relax and enjoy the view of Puebla!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

250024442.name: Nice views
250024442.author: a TripAdvisor user
250024442.reviewBody: We took a taxi to the fort and then walked back to the zocola. The views were great and the coffee shop just down from the fort was a nice place to sit and see the city. The fort had information in both English and Spanish.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

244077317.name: Doesn\u00b4t live up to the hype
244077317.author: a TripAdvisor user
244077317.reviewBody:
Whenever we think of Puebla, we think of "5 de Mayo". A holiday that´s even more popular in the US than in Mexico. And the famous 5 de Mayo date comes from a battle between Mexico and France. When talking about this battle, the most important place was “Fuertes de Loreto”.
Because of this, I thought it was going to be this amazing place with several “Fuertes”. Well, it wasn´t. It was only one of them and kind of small.
The museum was informative, but I was expecting a little more.
Now for the location, that was a totally different experience, I really liked it. They have a “mirador” from where you can see the City of Puebla and a small artificial lake. About a minute drive away we can also find some nice museums. 
Overall, the whole area is pretty nice.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

237645522.name: Basically nice view
237645522.author: a TripAdvisor user
237645522.reviewBody: The place offers one of the best views in Puebla, very nicely built new complex with a water/light show at night, 8:45pm from Thursday to Sunday, which is ok\'d., the fort is also very simple but nicely kept, nothing special youth the whole place but the view

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

235416981.name: Worth a visit
235416981.author: a TripAdvisor user
235416981.reviewBody: This old Fort tells a great deal about the Mexican history and struggle for independance.  There are not too many "displays" but the views of the city from the forts walls are awesome.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

225818069.name: Great little adventure, especially for kids
225818069.author: a TripAdvisor user
225818069.reviewBody: Our kids loved the fort; the canons and fort itself made history come alive.  The only downfall to this place is the lack of public transportation that goes directly to the fort.  We took a cab there,and planned to take a bus back but at the end took a cab back to the z\u00f3calo.  The two way street has zooming cars and buses and a tiny space in which to take the return bus.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

203670738.name: Cinco de Mayo and a beautiful park with multiple activities.
203670738.author: a TripAdvisor user
203670738.reviewBody: This is the site where the battle of Cinco de Mayo took place. Currently there is a huge park in the area. There is a museum and cathedral dedicated to the battle of Cinco de Mayo. There is also a lake where you can rent paddleboats, many splash pad areas for children to play in, many beautiful views on all sides of the park, trails, exercise equipment, statues. There are other museums in the park besides the couple dedicated to Cinco de Mayo. There is also ample free parking.\nThis place made me wish I had my 5 year old son with me...he would have loved it here.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

202427323.name: Cinco De Mayo.
202427323.author: a TripAdvisor user
202427323.reviewBody: If you think Cinco de Mayo is having a bunch of margaritas watching a football game with all your friends think again. It is actually a battle for independence fought in Puebla Mexico removing the French occupation off of Mexican soil. Mexicans drove the French all the way back to France. That\'s what the true Cinco de Mayo is actually about. The fort where the battle took place high on a hill overlooking the city and has a wonderful new set of museums up there that you can explore and find everything that\'s available about the history. Well worth a look.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

201411851.name: Only Decent Green Space In Puebla
201411851.author: a TripAdvisor user
201411851.reviewBody: I didn\'t have a clue where I was going.  The hill looked tempting and despite the heat wave and the record air pollution I climbed to the top passing gated haciendas, a hotel and a sports stadium, then several monuments till I arrived at a park full of trees.  During this visit to Mexico I was suffering from museum fatigue so I didn\'t bother checking out the museums (full disclosure: on my first of three visits to las Fuertes I had done no research and assumed I was on the border of a university campus, then one of the staff in my hotel corrected me and said they were mostly museums and memorials and sites of public interest.) I didn\'t really care about any of that at the time, I just wanted some trees and quiet green space which the park on top of the hill provides aplenty and which Puebla, generally, completely lacks.  You can also take a walk that encompasses the entire hill providing a great view of Puebla and the volcanoes (even better when the air is clean).  There is also a great caf\u00e9 there, curiously named caf\u00e9 York.  They have a deck outside and even from inside the view (when the air is clean) is incomparable.  \n     It is a bit of a climb but worth it for what\'s on top and great exercise too.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

198843282.name: go for the history
198843282.author: a TripAdvisor user
198843282.reviewBody: Poblanos defeated the French, the best army in the world at that time. The fort has been modernize, cement walls with white paint. I would have liked to see it more original. Worth the visit if you have the time.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

193599953.name: Must see fort, park has much to see
193599953.author: a TripAdvisor user
193599953.reviewBody: The view from the fort is worth trip.  The area in which the fort is located is a beautiful park with ire museums to see and a nice place to walk and enjoy the view.   The museum within the walls of the fort tells the story of Puebla very well.  There is much to see and worth going.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

189923350.name: Wonderful Experience
189923350.author: a TripAdvisor user
189923350.reviewBody: Great site/park for learning much of the very complicated political (and cultural) history of Mexico- to include 5 de Mayo!

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

185584775.name: Excellent opportunity to learn about Mexco\'s past
185584775.author: a TripAdvisor user
185584775.reviewBody: One of many cultural/historical attractions in this large civic park, it hosts a wonderful and varied collection of fascinating items.  Museums are free on Sundays! Can\'t beat that value. When you arrive you are asked to take a seat and wait for the next organized tours. It won\u2019t be longer than 20 minutes. Beware, all the museums and military forts at this park  shut down their doors one hour before the official closing time.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

177796478.name: Very Interesting, and Few Tourists
177796478.author: a TripAdvisor user
177796478.reviewBody: I took a cab to the "Zona de los Fuertes" because I\'m a history buff, and I wanted to see them.  Guadalupe was closed, but there were some nice views.  Loreto was fantastic!  A beautiful structure, and a very nice little museum.  I thoroughly enjoyed my time there, and I was the only tourist there.  The $46 peso entry fee seemed fair for the museum.\n\nAfterwards, I walked back down the hill to the Centro.  It\'s not too far, and a nice walk.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

174747616.name: Fuertes de Loreto
174747616.author: a TripAdvisor user
174747616.reviewBody: Learn more about your U.S. history while learning about M\u00e9xico\'s. Although you can walk there from the z\u00f3calo, it\'s quite an uphill trek. Take the bus and you can spend more time at the Fuertes, in my opinion.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

165097535.name: The past and the present
165097535.author: a TripAdvisor user
165097535.reviewBody: These are the remains of the Forts of Loreto and Guadalupe which used to be used to guard the city of Puebla.\nThe view is great. Here you can see the whole city of Puebla and in a clear day up to the volcanoes: Popocatepetl and Iztaccihuatl. Besides here are several Museums, a Planetarium, an Auditorium for classic mucic concerts and the huge Expo Center in the whole state of Puebla.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

153813021.name: Very Interesting and a Great Place to get Photos of Popo
153813021.author: a TripAdvisor user
153813021.reviewBody: It is a nice place to spend some free time but it has a great vantage point for photos. On a clear day you can get wonderful photos of the active volcano - Popo or an aerial view of Puebla. A lot of work was done recently and if you go at night the fountains are a lot of fun to watch with different color lights and music.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

153799696.name: Great for history buffs
153799696.author: a TripAdvisor user
153799696.reviewBody: The "Cinco de Mayo Civic Center" is a public city park that encompasses a large hill north of the downtown of Puebla. At the top of the hill is the Fort of Guadalupe which is the larger of two forts here which were involved in the defense of Puebla at the battle of Cinco de Mayo, 1862. The museum complex also includes the smaller (but older) Fort of Loreto further down the hill, which has a better museum than the larger fort, explaining a lot about the history of the forts and the famous battle.\n\nBetween the two forts is a very pretty park where many of the people of Puebla come with their families on beautiful days like the one when we went. There is the regional museum of Puebla (state museum), the "Imagina" interactive childrens museum, and the city planetarium. The Planetarium was especially neat, as it has a lot of interactive exhibits as well as an IMAX dome theater with shows about every two hours (included in admission fee). The park also has plenty of picnic tables and open areas that are good to just relax in.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

146587993.name: INTERESTING BUT NOT A MUST
146587993.author: a TripAdvisor user
146587993.reviewBody: This place has historic interest, since from there the Mexicans defeated, against every prevision, a French invasion. The forts, of Spanish characteristics, are well preserved in their bare structure, not presenting in that much appeal, but they hold expositions related to the said combats, and those exhibitions are well prepared. Nice views of the city from the surroundings.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

141616780.name: 5 de Mayo
141616780.author: a TripAdvisor user
141616780.reviewBody: Took a tour of the fuerte, was a very patriotic day,learned a lot of Mexican history.Believe it or not, this place is a must to see.

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

130434302.name: A remodeled look
130434302.author: a TripAdvisor user
130434302.reviewBody: This whole area was much different from when we first visited several years ago. You can tell a lot of work has been put into making it a beautiful monument to Puebla

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

128343686.name: Only if you want to learn about Mexican Revolution
128343686.author: a TripAdvisor user
128343686.reviewBody: It\'s great to learn all about this places, but there is no more value if you are not in the mood to learn about Mexican Revolution

address.streetAddress: Av Ejercito de Ote S/N Corner with Calzada de los Fuertes street

644846883.name: Nice park, kids will love it
644846883.author: a TripAdvisor user
644846883.reviewBody: Don\'t know where it\'s name came from but it\'s a very nice park to walk through and is a great place to visit if the tourist crowded get too much for you or if you just can\'t visit one more church.

591706407.name: Beautiful Park
591706407.author: a TripAdvisor user
591706407.reviewBody: This is a great park to go camping, it has some rivers and mountains where you can go to see the nature.\nIt is cold at night and also it rains a lot. Just don\u00b4t forget a jacket and some raining clothes.

438103148.name: Impressive views
438103148.author: a TripAdvisor user
438103148.reviewBody: This is a very exciting place to visit, which I enjoyed a lot, if possible try to do the ride trip inside. Bring a jacket or sweater because it is a cold place and you may be surrounded by fog.

415421480.name: Incredible!
415421480.author: a TripAdvisor user
415421480.reviewBody: We had a great time. The children enjoyed to climb the rocks. They ran all over the place, and enjoy the wind and the breeze. This place has horses, wagons, donkeys to rent. They have a camping area. This place is located in Zacatlan, Puebla.

322437565.name: Beautiful Scenery enjoyed on horseback
322437565.author: a TripAdvisor user
322437565.reviewBody: This was our second time visiting Piedras Encimadas. This time we brought some visiting family with us.  The scenery is beautiful, but mostly we come because they have an hour horseback ride for only 150 pesos and my girls love riding. The grounds are kept up nicely and some guides are better at others in helping you see the formations in the rocks. Other options are walking and biking, or a big wagon behind a horse for about 6 people. There is an area for camping and a nice stream runs through the grounds. Everyone we\'ve met has been welcoming and friendly. We generally try to get there as early in the morning as possible because the clouds and fog set in around noon, plus it\'s pretty empty. Their hours, as of Oct. 2015 are 9am-6pm.

288686146.name: Do not miss!
288686146.author: a TripAdvisor user
